column62: Section 4
column63: Chapter 1
column64: shall be amended by striking out Units B and C (original concessions)
column65:
and by inserting in lieu thereof Units B and C in Appendix A to this Agreement (substitute converted concessions) which omit Note 6 of Unit C.
Article 4
Further Tariff Reductions
(a) Explanation Article provides for the following tariff concessions by the United States on certain chemicals and other articles
column66: not covered by Article 3
column67: in return for the concessions provided for herein by the other parties to this Agreement:\n(i) paragraph (b)(i) of this Article repeals General Note 3(f) of Schedule XX
column68: which provides that
column69: in the absence of the additional concessions by the other parties to this Agreement
column70: the United States will interrupt the staging of concessions on certain chemicals and other articles so that such concessions do not exceed two-fifths of each reduction to the full concession rate. With respect to such articles
column71: as they are identified by item numbers in Appendix B to this Agreement
column72: the United States is prepared to make the remaining three-fifths of such reduction in return for the additional concessions from the other parties
column73: and\n(ii) paragraph (b)(ii) of this Article amends Schedule XX by deleting original concessions on certain additional chemicals and other articles and substituting therefor concessions which provide for full concession rates
column74: constituting reductions in excess of 50 % set forth in Appendix C to this Agreement.\n(b) Amendments\nUpon the entry into force of this Agreement
column75: Schedule XX shall be amended:\n(i) by striking out General Note 3(f); this repeals
column76: as of the effective date of the amendment
column77: the provision for interruption of the staging of the concessions provided for in the items listed in Appendix B; and after such date the effectiveness of such concessions (including any further staging thereof) shall be. governed by the provisions of General Note 3
column78: computing any relevant time periods from the effective date of the original concessions
column79: as though there had . been no provision for interruption of staging
column80: and\n(ii) by striking out the rate in each item in Schedule XX (original concession) which has the same item number as an item set forth in Appendix C

and in each case inserting in lieu thereof the rate in such item in Appendix C (substitute concession exceeding 50 %).
SUB-PART B — STAGING OF SUBSTITUTE CONCESSIONS
Articles 5
Coordination of Staging
(a) Explanation
This Article provides for the staging of the substitute converted concessions provided for in Appendix A and of the substitute concessions exceeding 50 % provided for in Appendix C. It does so by inserting a new General Note 3(f) in Schedule XX and by adding a new Annex I-A to that Schedule. New General Note 3(f) assimilates the staging of the substitute concessions with the staging of the original concessions for which they are substituted. Although rates will be changed by the amendment

column84: for both kinds of substitute concessions rates applicable during the first
column85: second

ITALY
SUB-PART A — CHEMICALS
Article 6
Further Tariff Reductions
(a) Explanation
This Article amends Schedule XL (European Economic Community)
column125: Part 1
column126: annexed to the Protocol (hereinafter referred to as Schedule XL)
column127: so as to provide for the further tariff concessions on chemicals and other articles granted by the European Economic Community under this Agreement
column128: in return for the additional concessions provided for herein by the other parties to this Agreement. These further tariff concessions are provided for in Chapters 28 through 39 of Schedule XL and are subject to the following four General Rules:\n(i) The first General Rule applies to those tariff items in Chapters 28 through 39 which are identified by the symbol \"C1\" in the fourth column and which are subject to base rates of duty of less than 25 % ad valorem (or equivalent); the concessions on these rates consist of four tenths of each reduction to the final rate
column129: which shall be made under the Protocol at the same time as the first two stages thereunder
column130: and
column131: upon the entry into force of this Agreement
column132: the remaining six tenths of such reduction
column133: which shall be made at the same time as the remaining stages under the Protocol.\n(ii) The second General Rule applies to those tariff items in Chapters 28 through 39 which are identified by the symbol \"C2\" and which are subject to base rates of duty of 25 % ad valorem (or equivalent) or more; the concessions on these rates consist of six. tenths of each reduction to the final rate
column134: which shall be made under the Protocol at the same time as the first three stages thereunder
column135: and
column136: upon entry into force of this Agreement
column137: the remaining four tenths of such reduction
column138: which shall be made at the same time as the remaining stages under the Protocol.\n(iii) The third General Rule applies to these tariff items in Chapters 28 through 39 which are identified by the symbol \"C3\" and with respect to which Switzerland has been the principal or a substantial supplier of the articles concerned to the European Economic Community; the concessions on these rates consist of seven tenths of each reduction to the final rate
column139: which shall be made under the Protocol at the same time as the first four stages thereunder
column140: and
column141: upon entry into force of this Agreement
column142: the remaining three tenths of such reduction
column143: of which one tenth shall be added to the reduction made at the same time as the fourth stage and two tenths shall be made at the same time as the last stage under the Protocol.\n(iv) The fourth General Rule applies to those tariff items in Chapters 28 through 39 which are identified by the symbol \"C4\" and which are duty free; the concessions on these items consist of the binding of duty-free treatment which shall be made upon the entry into force of this Agreement.\nThe tariff items in Chapters 28 through 39 of Schedule XL for which concessions or other actions do not conform with any of the four General Rules
column144: and tariff items in Chapters 28 through 39 of the tariff of the European Economic Community (other than items presently bound duty free)
column145: for which no concessions are made
column146: are listed in Appendix E to this Agreement.\n(b) Amendments\nUpon the entry into force of this Agreement
column147: Schedule XL shall be amended by striking out the seventh
column148: eighth
column149: ninth and tenth paragraphs under Section II of the General Notes at the beginning of this Schedule

thereby rendering applicable the final rates in such Chapters.
SUB-PART B -AUTOMOBILE ROAD TAXES
Article 7
High-Cylinder Capacity Engines
(a) Explanation
There follows the text of the undertaking relating to automobile road taxes on the part of Belgium
column155: France
column156: and Italy
column157: in return for the additional concessions provided for herein by the other parties to this Agreement.\n(b) Undertaking\nUpon the entry into force of this Agreement the Governments of Belgium
column158: France
column159: and Italy shall set in motion the necessary constitutional procedures in order to adjust the modalities of their automobile road taxes concerning either the progressivity of the taxes or the basis of the taxes

so as to assure the absence of those elements of these taxes whose incidence is particularly heavy for vehicles having engines of a high-cylinder capacity.
PART IV
UNITED KINGDOM
SUB-PART A — CHEMICALS
Article 8
Further Tariff Reductions
(a) Explanation
This Article amends Schedule XIX (United Kingdom)
column162: Section A
column163: Part I
column164: annexed to the Protocol (hereinafter referred to as Schedule XIX)
column165: so as to provide for the further tariff concessions on chemicals and other articles granted by the United Kingdom under this Agreement

These further tariff concessions are provided for in Chapters 28 through 39 of Schedule XIX (in which concessions under the Protocol are enclosed in brackets and final concessions are without brackets) and are subject to the following four General Rules:\n(i) The first General Rule applies to those tariff items in Chapters 28 through 38 which are subject to base rates of duty of less than 25 % ad valorem (or equivalent); the concessions on these rates consist of two fifths of each reduction to the final rate which shall be made under the Protocol at the same time as the first two stages thereunder
column167: and
column168: upon the entry into force of this Agreement
column169: the remaining three fifths of such reduction which shall be made at the same time as the remaining stages under the Protocol.\n(ii) The second General Rule applies to those tariff items in Chapters 28 through 38 which are subject to base rates of duty of 25 % ad valorem (or equivalent) or more; the concessions on these rates consist of reductions of 30 %
column170: which shall be made under the Protocol at the same time as the first three stages thereunder
column171: and
column172: upon the entry into force of this Agreement
column173: further reductions to a rate not greater than 12
column174: 5 % ad valorem
column175: which shall be made at the same time as the remaining stages under the Proto-col.\n(iii) The third General Rule
column176: applies to those items in Chapters 28 through 38 which are identified by an asterisk
column177: the concessions on these rates consist of reductions of 35 %
column178: which shall be made under the Protocol at the same time as the first three or four stages thereunder
column179: and
column180: upon entry into force of this Agreement
column181: further reductions to the final rate
column182: which shall be made at the same time as the last two stages
column183: under the Protocol.\n(iv) The fourth General Rule applies to the tariff items in Chapter 39; the concessions on these items under the Protocol consist of reductions in those base rates which are equal to
column185: fee base rates on the same items in Chapter 39 of Schedule XL of the European Economic Community
column186: and these reductions shall be made under the Protocol in accordance with the first or second General Rule
column187: whichever is applicable; no concessions (indicated by empty brackets) shall be made under the Protocol on base rates which are lower than the base rates on the same items in Chapter 39 of Schedule XL; the concessions under this Agreement consist of reductions or further reductions to the final rates on the same items in Chapter 39 of Schedule XL
column188: which shall be made at the same time as the remaining stages under the Protocol
column189: and of bindings of base rates which are not higher than the final rates on the same items in Chapter 39 of Schedule XL.\nThe tariff items in Chapters 28 through 39 of Schedule XIX (other than items to be bound duty free) for which concessions do not satisfy the conditions of any of these four General Rules
column190: and items in Chapters 28 through 39 of the United Kingdom''s tariff
column191: other than items presently bound duty free
column192: for which no concessions are made
column193: are listed in Appendix F to this Agreement.\n(b) Amendments\nUpon the entry into force of this Agreement

column195: and\n(ii) by striking out in Chapters 28 through 39 all the brackets and bracketed rates in the fourth column

Article 9
Reduction of Preference Margin in Revenue Duty
(a) Explanation
This Article amends Schedule XIX so as to insert therein the note set forth below. By the terms of this note
column197: the United Kingdom will reduce by approximately 25 % the margin of Commonwealth preference in the revenue duty on unmanufactured tobacco
column198: in return for the additional concessions provided for herein by the other parties to this Agreement.\n(b) Amendments\nUpon

shall be inserted after tariff item No 23.07 in Schedule XIX;
Note
1. Whenever the ordinary mosf-favoured-nation customs duty chargeable on unmanufactured tobacco containing 10 % or more by weight of moisture -
(a) is not more than £1.15s.6d. per pound
column204: that duty shall not exceed the preferential duty by more than 9d. per pound
column205: or\n(b) is more than \u00a3 1.15s.6d. per pound but not more than \u00a32. 5s.2d. per pound

that duty shall not exceed the preferential duty by more than ls.2d. per pound.
2. The ordinary most-favoured-nation customs duty charge able on unmanufactured tobacco containing less than 10 % by weight of moisture shall not exceed the preferential duty by more than ls.31/2d. per pound.’
PART V — SWITZERLAND
Article 10
Prepared Fruit
(a) Explanation
This Article amends Schedule LIX (Switzerland)
column210: annexed to the Protocol (hereinafter referred to as Schedule LIX) so as to insert therein the note set forth below. By the terms of this note
column211: Switzerland shall assure that prepared or preserved fruits provided for in tariff item No 2006 shall be free from restrictions by reason of the presence of com syrup
column212: in return for the additional concessions provided for therein by the other parties to this Agreement.\n(b) Amendments\nUpon the entry into force of this Agreement
column213:
the following note shall be inserted after item No 2006 in Schedule LIX:
"Note:
Imports of prepared or preserved fruits under tariff item No 2006 shall be free of any restrictions imposed by reason of the presence of corn syrup".
PART VI
FINAL PROVISIONS
Article 11
Significance of Explanations
The explanations set out in this Agreement are intended for convenience only in referring to the amendments and undertaking and have no legal force or effect whatsoever.
Article 12
Signature and Acceptance
This Agreement shall be open for acceptance
column221: the United States and by the European Economic Community
column222:
and if accepted by all those Governments and the European Economic Community by the latter date it shall enter into force in accordance with the provisions of Article 1 (b).
Article 13
Deposit with Director-General
This Agreement shall be deposited with the Director-General to the contracting parties who shall promptly furnish a certified copy thereof
column223: and a report of the notification received by him pursuant to Article 1 (b) of this Agreement
column224:
to each contracting party to the General Agreement and to the European Economic Community.
Article 14
Registration with United Nations
This Agreement shall be registered in accordance with the provisions of Article 102 of the Charter of the United Nations.
Done at Geneva this thirtieth day of June one thousand nine hundred and sixty-seven

ANNEX C
Memorandum of Agreement on basic elements for the negotiation of a world grains arrangement
The Governments of Argentina
column17: Canada
column19: Finland
column20: Japan
column21: Norway
column22: Sweden
column23: Switzerland
column24: the United Kingdom
column25: the United States
column26:
and the European Economic Community and its member States
Have agreed as follows:
Article 1
Each signatory to this Agreement agrees to negotiate a world grains arrangement
column27: on as wide a basis as possible
column28: in a conference promptly called for such purpose
column29: that contains the provisions set form in Article 2
column30: to work diligently for the early conclusion of the negotiation
column31:
and upon completion of the negotiation to seek acceptance of the arrangement in accordance with its constitutional procedures as rapidly as possible.
Article 2
PRINCIPAL ITEMS OF WORLD GRAINS
Arrangement
I. Pricing provisions
1. The schedule of minimum and maximum prices
column32: basis fob Gulf ports
column33:
is established for the duration of this arrangement as follows:

2. The minimum prices and maximum prices for the specified Canadian and US wheats
column35: fob Pacific NW ports shall be 6 cents less than the prices in paragraph 1.\n3. The schedule of minimum prices may be adjusted in accordance with the provisions of IV below.\n4. The minimum price and maximum price for FAQ Australian wheat fob Australian ports shall be 5 cents below the price equivalent to the c. and f. price in United Kingdom ports of the minimum price and maximum price for US Hard Red Winter No. 2 (ordinary)
column36: fob Gulf ports
column37: specified in paragraph 1
column38: computed by using currently prevailing transportation costs.\n5. The minimum prices and maximum prices for Argentine wheat
column39: fob Argentine ports
column40: for destinations bordering the Pacific and Indian Oceans
column41: shall be the prices equivalent to the c. and f. prices in Yokohama of the minimum prices and maximum prices for US 2 Hard Red Winter (ordinary) wheat fob Pacific NW ports
column42: specified in paragraph 2
column43: computed by using currently prevailing transportation costs.\n6. The minimum prices and maximum prices for\n- the specified US wheats
column44: fob US Atlantic
column45: Great Lakes and Canadian St. Lawrence ports
column46: \n- the specified Canadian wheats
column47: fob Ft. William/Port Arthur
column48: St. Lawrence ports
column49: Atlantic ports
column50: and Churchill
column51: \n- Argentine wheat
column52: fob Argentine ports
column53: for destinations other than those specified in paragraph 5
column54: \nshall be the prices equivalent to the c and f prices in Antwerp/Rotterdam of the minimum prices and maximum prices specified in paragraph 1
column55: computed by using currently prevailing transportation costs.\n7. The minimum prices and maximum prices for the EEC standard wheat shall be the prices equivalent to the c. and f. price in the country of destination
column56: or the c. and f. price at an appropriate port for delivery to the country of destination
column57: of the minimum prices and maximum prices for Hard Winter No. 2 (ordinary) wheat fob United States
column58: specified in paragraphs 1 and 2
column59: computed by using currently prevailing transportation costs and by applying the price adjustments corresponding to the agreed quality differences set forth in the scale of equivalents.\n8. The minimum prices and maximum prices for Swedish wheat shall be the prices equivalent to the c. and f. price in the country of destination
column60: or the c. and f. price at an appropriate port for delivery to the country of destination
column61: of the minimum prices and maximum prices for Hard Winter No. 2 (ordinary) wheat fob United States
column62: specified in paragraphs 1 and 2
column63:
computed by using currently prevailing transportation costs and by applying the price adjustments corresponding to the agreed quality differences set forth in the scale of equivalents.
II. Commercial purchases and supply commitments
1. Each member country when exporting wheat undertakes to do so at prices consistent with the price range.
2. Each member country importing wheat undertakes that the maximum possible share of its total commercial purchases of wheat in any crop year shall be purchased from member countries
column64: except as provided in paragraph 4 below. This share will have to be determined at a later stage and will be dependent upon the extent to which other countries accede to the Arrangement.\n3. Exporting countries undertake
column65: in association with one another
column66:
that wheat from their countries shall be made available for purchase by importing countries in any crop year at prices consistent with the price range in quantities sufficient to satisfy on a regular and continuous basis the commercial requirements of those countries subject to the other provisions of this Agreement.
4. Under extraordinary circumstances a member country may be granted by the Council partial exemption from the commitment contained in paragraph 2 upon submission of satisfactory supporting evidence to the Council.
5. Each member country when importing wheat from non-member countries shall undertake to do so at prices consistent with the price range.
III. Role of maximum prices
1. The role of maximum prices shall be in general conformity with that set forth in the International Wheat Agreement of 1962.
2. Provision shall be made for continuous review by the Secretariat of the Grains Council of the situation with regard to the arrangements in respect of maximum prices and for initiating the necessary action.
3. Durum wheat and certified seed wheat shall be excluded from the provisions relating to maximum prices.
IV. Role of minimum prices
The purpose of the schedule of minimum prices is to contribute to market stability by making it possible to determine when the level of market prices for any wheat is at or approaching the minimum of the range. Since price relationships between types and qualities of wheat fluctuate with competitive circumstances
column67: provision is made for review of and adjustments in minimum prices
column68: on the basis of the following principles:\n1. If the Secretariat of the Grains Council in the course of its continuous review of market conditions is of the opinion that a situation has arisen
column69: or threatens imminently to arise
column70: which appears to jeopardize the objectives of the Arrangement with regard to the minimum price provisions
column71: or if such a situation is called to the attention of the Secretariat of the Council by any member country
column72: the Executive Secretary shall convene a meeting of the Prices Review Committee within two days and concurrently notify all member countries.\n2. The Prices Review Committee shall review the price situation with the view to reaching agreement on action required by member participants to restore price stability and to maintain prices at or above minimum levels and shall notify the Executive Secretary when agreement has been reached and of the action taken to restore market stability.\n3. If after three market days the Prices Review Committee is unable to reach agreement on the action to be taken to restore market stability
column73: the Chairman of the Council shall convene a meeting of the Council within two days to consider what further measures might be taken. If after not more than three days of review by the Council any member country is exporting or offering wheat below the minimum prices as determined by the Council
column74: the Council shall decide whether provisions of the agreement shall be suspended and if so to what extent.\n4. When any minimum price has been adjusted in accordance with the foregoing
column75:
such adjustments shall terminate when the Prices Review Committee or the Council finds that the conditions requiring the adjustments no longer prevail.
5. Denatured wheat shall be excluded from the provisions relating to minimum prices.
V. International food aid
1. The countries party to this Agreement agree to contribute wheat
column76: coarse grains
column77: or the cash equivalent thereof
column78: as aid to the developing countries
column79: to an amount of 4
column80:
5 million metric tons of grain annually. Grains covered by the programme shall be suitable for human consumption and of an acceptable type and quality.
2. The minimum contribution of each country party to this Agreement is fixed as follows:
| % | (‘000 metric tons) |
United States | 42

0 | 225 |
Countries acceding to the Arrangement may make contributions on such a basis as may be agreed.
3. The contribution of a country making the whole or part of its contribution to the programme in the form of cash shall be calculated by evaluating the quantity determined for that country (or that portion of the quantity not contributed in grain) at US$1.73 per bushel.
4. Food aid in the form of grain shall be supplied on the following terms:
(a) Sales for the currency of the importing country which is not transferable and is not convertible into currency or goods and services for use by the contributing country. [1]
(b) A gift of grain or a monetary grant used to purchase grain for the importing country.
Grain purchases shall be made from participating countries. In the use of grant funds
column93: special regard shall be had to facilitating grain exports of developing member countries. To this end priority shall be given so that not less than 25 % of the cash contribution to purchase grain for food aid or that part of such contribution required to purchase 200000 metric tons of grain shall be used to purchase grains produced in developing countries. Contributions in the form of grains shall be placed in fob forward position by donor countries.\n5. Countries party to the Arrangement may
column94: in respect of their . contribution to the food aid programme
column95: specify a recipient country or countries.\nVI. Miscellaneous\nA grains arrangement must include
column96: among other things
column97: acceptable provisions relating to such issues as voting rights
column98: definition of commercial transactions
column99: guidelines for non-commercial transactions
column100: safeguards for commercial transactions
column101:
and provisions concerning wheat flour which take into account the special nature of international trade in flour.
VII. Duration
The Arrangement shall be effective for a three-year period.
VIII. Accession
The terms and conditions of accession of countries not original signatories to this Agreement shall be decided upon in subsequent negotiations.
IX. Subsequent negotiations
Nothing in subsequent negotiations shall prejudice the commitments undertaken in this Memorandum of Agreement.
Article 3
This Memorandum of Agreement shall be opened for acceptance by signature on 30 June 1967 and shall enter into force when accepted by the Governments of Argentina
column102: Australia
column103: Canada
column104: Denmark
column105: Finland
column106: Japan
column107: Norway
column108: Sweden
column109: Switzerland
column110: the United Kingdom
column111: and the United States
column112: and by the European Economic Community and its Member States.\nArticle 4\nThis Memorandum of Agreement shall be deposited with the Director-General to the Contracting Parties
column113:
who shall promptly furnish a certified copy thereof to each contracting party to the General Agreement and to the European Economic Community.
Article 5
This Memorandum of Agreement shall be registered in accordance with the provisions of Article 102 of the Charter of the United Nations.
Done at Geneva this thirtieth day of June one thousand nine hundred and sixty-seven in a single copy in the English and French languages
column114: both texts being authentic.\n[1] Under exceptional circumstances an exception of not more than 10 per cent could be granted\n--------------------------------------------------"'

COUNCIL DECISION of 20 July 1970 on the conclusion of the Protocol for the Accession of the United Arab Republic to GATT (70/376/EEC)
  THE COUNCIL OF THE EUROPEAN COMMUNITIES
column18: \n Having regard to the Treaty establishing the European Economic Community
column19: and in particular Article 113 thereof; \n Having regard to the report from the Commission; \n Whereas during the 1964-67 Trade Conference the United Arab Republic entered into tariff negotiations with the European Economic Community
column20: as required for its accession to the General Agreement
column21:
and whereas these negotiations were completed on 13 March 1970; 
 Whereas the tariff concessions granted by the United Arab Republic in return for the tariff advantages that country obtains as a result of its accession to the General Agreement are acceptable; 
 Whereas a list of the tariff concessions granted by the United Arab Republic is annexed to the Protocol for the Accession of that country to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. 
 HAS DECIDED AS FOLLOWS:
 
   Article 1
 The Protocol for the Accession of the United Arab Republic to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade is concluded. 
 The Protocol is annexed to this Decision. 
 
 Article 2
 The President of the Council is hereby authorized to designate the person empowered to sign the Protocol for the Accession of the United Arab Republic and to confer on him the powers required in order to bind the Community.
 
 
   Done at Brussels
column22:
20 July 1970 
 For the Council 
 The President 
 W. SCHEEL 
 
 
ANNEX PROTOCOL for the Accession of the United Arab Republic to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade
 The Governments which are contracting parties to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (herinafter referred to as "contracting parties" and "the General Agreement" respectively) ; The European Economic Community and the Government of the United Arab Republic (hereinafter referred to as "the United Arab Republic"); 
 Taking note of the request of the United Arab Republic for accession to the General Agreement
column23: and of the discussions leading to the Declaration on the Provisional Accession of the United Arab Republic
column25: upon entry into force of this Protocol pursuant to paragraph 8
column26: become a contracting party to the General Agreement
column27: as defined in Article XXXII thereof
column28: and shall apply provisionally and subject to this Protocol:    (a) Parts I
column29: III and IV of the General Agreement
column30:
and 
      (b) Part II of the General Agreement to the fullest extent not inconsistent with its legislation existing on the date of this Protocol. 
 
 
 The obligations incorporated in paragraph 1 of Article 1 by reference to Article III and those incorporated in paragraph 2 (b) of Article II by reference to Article VI of the General Agreement shall be considered as falling within Part II for the purpose of this paragraph. 
 2.  (a) The provisions of the General Agreement to be applied by the United Arab Republic shall
column31: except as otherwise provided in this Protocol
column32: be the provisions contained in the text annexed to the Final Act of the second session of the Preparatory Committee of the United Nations Conference on Trade and Employment
column33: as rectified
column34: amended
column35: or otherwise modified by such instruments as may have become effective on the day on which the United Arab Republic becomes a contracting party. \n (b)  (i) Notwithstanding the provisions of paragraph 1 of Article 1 of the General Agreement
column36: this Protocol shall not require the elimination by the United Arab Republic of any preferences in respect of import duties or charges accorded by the United Arab Republic exclusive to one or more of the following countries: Jordan
column37: Syria
column38: Iraq
column39: Lebanon
column40: Libya
column41: Saudi Arabia and Yemen
column42: provided
column43: however
column44: that these preferences do not exceed the levels in effect on 13 November 1962; \n (ii) the preceding paragraph shall be deemed to be a Decision of the contracting parties under Article XXV : 5 of the General Agreement as if it were a Decision pursuant to paragraph 3 of Article I; \n (iii) in the event that the United Arab Republic should at some future date desire to modify the preferences referred to in subparagraph (i) above
column45: including the addition of products not at present subject to preference
column46: the matter shall be dealt with by the contracting parties in accordance with paragraph 3 of Article I of the General Agreement: \n (iv) nothing in subparagraphs (i)
column47: (ii) and (iii) above shall affect the rights of the United Arab Republic with respect to the provisions of the General Agreement relating to the formation of a customs union or a free trade area. \n \n      (c) In each case in which paragraph 6 of Article V
column48: subparagraph 4 (d) of Article VII
column49: and subparagraph 3 (c) of Article X of the General Agreement refer to the date of that Agreement
column50: the applicable date in respect of the United Arab Republic shall be 13 November 1962
column51:
the date of the Declaration providing for the Provisional Accession of the United Arab Republic to the General Agreement. 
 
 
  PART II Schedule
 3. The schedule in the Annex shall
column52: upon the entry into force of this Protocol
column53: become a Schedule to the General Agreement relating to the United Arab Republic.  \n 4. Should certain negotiations not be completed in time for the results to be annexed to this Protocol when it is opened for signature
column54: any further concessions resulting from those negotiations shall be annexed to this Protocol
column55: and shall be governed by the provisions thereof
column56: as from the day following the signature of a Proc\u00e8s-Verbal by the interested parties. \n 5. (a) In each case in which paragraph 1 of Article II of the General Agreement refers to the date of that Agreement
column57: the applicable date in respect of each product which is the subject of a concession provided for in the schedule annexed to this Protocol shall be the date of this Protocol. \n (b) For the purpose of the reference in paragraph 6 (a) of Article II of the General Agreement to the date of that Agreement
column58: the applicable date in respect of the schedule annexed to this Protocol shall be the date of this Protocol. \n 6. The temporary \"consolidation of economic development tax\" may be maintained in effect
column59: at rates not exceeding the rates in force on the date of this Protocol
column60: on bound duties until 31 December 1975
column61: by which time
column62: if the measure is still in effect
column63:
the matter shall be reviewed by the contracting parties. 
  PART III Final provisions
 7. This Protocol shall be deposited with the Director General to the contracting parties. It shall be open for signature by the United Arab Republic until 31 December 1970. It shall also be open for signature by contracting parties and the European Economic Community. 
 8. This Protocol shall enter into force on the thirtieth day following the day upon which it shall have been signed by the United Arab Republic. 
 9. The United Arab Republic
column64: having become a contracting party to the General Agreement pursuant to paragraph 1 of this Protocol
column65: may accede to the General Agreement upon the applicable terms of this Protocol by deposit of an instrument of accession
column66: with the Director-General. Such accession shall take effect on the day on which the General Agreement enters into force pursuant to Article XXVI or on the thirtieth day following the day of the deposit of the instrument of accession
column67: whichever is the later. Accession to the General Agreement pursuant to this paragraph shall
column68: for the purpose of paragraph 2 of Article XXXII of that Agreement
column69: be regarded as acceptance of the Agreement pursuant to paragraph 4 of Article XXVI thereof. \n 10. The United Arab Republic may withdraw its provisional application of the General Agreement prior to its accession thereto pursuant to paragraph 9 and such withdrawal shall take effect on the sixtieth day following the day on which written notice thereof is received by the Director-General. \n 11. The Director-General shall promptly furnish a certified copy of this Protocol and a notification of each signature thereto pursuant to paragraph 7
column70: of the deposit of an instrument of accession pursuant to paragraph 9 and of a notice pursuant to paragraph 10 to each contracting party
column71: to the European Economic Community
column72: and to the United Arab Republic. \n 12. This Protocol shall be registered in accordance with the provisions of article 102 of the Charter of the United Nations. \n Done at Geneva this twenty-seventh day of February one thousand nine hundred and seventy

title: Agreement between the European Economic Community and Spain

Agreement between the European Economic Community and Spain  






Official Journal L 182
column15:
16/08/1970 P. 0002
 Danish special edition: Series II Volume I(1b) P. 0004 
 English special edition: Series II Volume I(1) P. 0270 
 Greek special edition: Chapter 11 Volume 1 P. 0121 
 












AGREEMENT between the European Economic Community and Spain (Only the Dutch
column17: German
column18: Italian and Spanish texts of this Agreement are authentic)\nTHE COUNCIL OF THE EUROPEAN COMMUNITIES
column19: of the one part
column20: and\nTHE SPANISH HEAD OF STATE
column21: of the other part
column24: President in Office of the Council of the European Communities
column25: Minister for Foreign Affairs;\nMr Jean Rey
column26: President of the Commission of the European Communities;\nTHE SPANISH HEAD OF STATE:\nMr Gregorio Lopez Bravo
column27: Minister for Foreign Affairs;\nWHO
column28: \nhaving exchanged their Full Powers
column29: found in good and due form
column30:
HAVE AGREED AS FOLLOWS:
Article 1
1. The progressive elimination of obstacles to the main body of trade between the European Economic Community and Spain shall be brought about in two stages
column31: as indicated below.\n2. The first stage shall last not less than six years.\n3. Transition from the first to the second stage shall be effected by mutual agreement between the Contracting Parties
column32:
if the conditions for it have been satisfied.
4. During the first stage the following provisions shall apply.
TITLE I
TRADE
Article 2
1. Products originating in Spain shall
column33: on importation into the Community
column34: be governed by the provisions of Annex I\n2. Products originating in the Community shall
column35: on importation into Spain
column36: be governed by the provisions of Annex II\n3. The Contracting Parties shall take all appropriate measures
column37: whether general or particular
column38:
to ensure fulfilment of the obligations arising out of the Agreement.
They shall refrain from any measure which could jeopardize the attainment of the objectives of this Agreement.
Article 3
Any internal fiscal measure or practice giving rise
column39: directly or indirectly
column40: to discrimination between the products of one Contracting Party and like products of the other Contracting Party shall be prohibited.\nArticle 4\nThe trading arrangements applied by Spain to products; o riginating in the Community or exported to the Community shall not give rise to any discrimination between the Member States
column41: their nationals or their companies or firms.\nThe trading arrangements applied by the Community to products originating in Spain or exported to Spain shall not give rise to any discrimination between Spanish nationals
column42: or between Spanish companies or firms.\nArticle 5\nSubject to special provisions relating to frontier-zone traffic
column43: the treatment applied by Spain to products originating in the Community shall in no case be less favourable than that applied to products originating in the most-favoured third State.\nArticle 6\nWhere duties are levied on products of one Contracting Party exported to the other Contracting Party
column44: such duties may not exceed those applied to products exported to the most-favoured third State.\nArticle 7\nArticles 5 and 6 shall not preclude the maintenance or establishment by Spain of customs unions or free-trade areas
column45: if these do not have the effect of modifying the trade arrangements laid down in the Agreement
column46:
and in particular the rules of origin.
Article 8
The rules of origin applicable to products covered by the Agreement are laid down in the Protocol.
Article 9
1. If one of the Contracting Parties finds in its relations with the other Contracting Party that dumping is being practised
column47: it may
column48: after consultations in the Joint Committee provided for in Article 13
column49: take protective measures against such practices in accordance with the provisions of the Agreement on the implementation of Article VI of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.\nIn urgent cases that Contracting Party may
column50: after notifying the Joint Committee
column51: apply the interim measures provided for by that Agreement. Consultations shall take place regarding such measures not later than two weeks after their implementation.\n2. Where measures are directed against bounties or subsidies
column52: the Contracting Parties undertake to comply with the provisions of Article VI of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.\n3. At the request of either Contracting Party
column53: consultations shall take place every three months in the Joint Committee on any observed dumping practices
column54: bounties or subsidies which are found to exist and on measures taken in regard thereto.\nArticle 10\nPayments relating to trade and the transfer of such payments to the Member State in which the creditor resides
column55: or to Spain
column56: shall not be subject to any restriction where such trade is covered by the provisions of this Agreement.\nArticle 11\n1. If serious disturbances occur in a sector of the Spanish economy or prejudice its external financial stability
column57: or if difficulties arise which adversely affect the economic situation in a region of Spain
column58: Spain may take the necessary protective measures.\nThe Joint Committee shall be notified immediately of such measures and of the rules for their application.\n2. If serious disturbances occur in a sector of the economy of the Community or of one or more Member States
column59: or prejudice the external financial stability of one or more Member States
column60: or if difficulties arise which adversely affect the economic situation in a region of the Community
column61: the Community may take
column62: or authorize the Member State or States concerned to take
column63: the necessary protective measures.\nThe Joint Committee shall be notified immediately of such measures and of the rules for their application.\n3. In the choice of measures to be taken in pursuance of paragraphs 1 and 2
column64:
preference shall be given to those which will least disturb the operation of the Agreement.
These measures shall not exceed what is strictly necessary to remedy the difficulties that have arisen.
4. Consultations may take place in the Joint Committee on the measures taken in pursuance of paragraphs 1 and 2.
Article 12
The provisions of the Agreement shall not preclude prohibitions or restrictions on imports
column65: exports or goods in transit justified on grounds of public morality
column66: public policy or public security; the protection of health and life of humans
column67: animals or plants ; the protection of national treasures possessing artistic
column68: historic or archaeological value; or the protection of industrial and commercial property. Such prohibitions or restrictions shall not
column69: however
column70:
constitute a means of arbitrary discrimination or a disguised restriction on trade.
TITLE II
GENERAL AND FINAL PROVISIONS
Article 13
1. A Joint Committee is hereby established to administer the Agreement and to ensure its proper execution. To this end it may may make recommendations. It shall take decisions as provided for in this Title.
2. The Contracting Parties agree to keep each other informed and
column71: at the request of either of them
column72:
to consult together in the Joint Committee to ensure that the Agreement is correctly implemented.
3. The Joint Committee shall adopt its rules of procedure by decision.
Article 14
1. The Joint Committee shall consist of representatives of the Community and representatives of Spain.
2. The Joint Committee shall act by mutual agreement.
Article 15
1. The Chairmanship of the Joint Committee shall be held alternately by each of the Contracting Parties
column73: in accordance with its rules of procedure.\n2. The Joint Committee shall meet once a year on the initiative of its Chairman.\nThe Joint Committee shall also meet whenever necessary
column74: at the request of either Contracting Party
column75:
in accordance with its rules of procedure.
3. The Joint Committee may decide to set up working parties to assist in the performance of its tasks.
Article 16
The Agreement may be denounced by either Contracting Party giving six months'' notice.
Article 17
1. The Agreement shall apply to the European territories where the Treaty establishing the European Economic Community applies and to the territory of Spain.
2. The Agreement shall apply also to the French overseas departments so far as concerns those of the fields covered by it which correspond to those listed in the first subparagraph of Article 227 (2) of the Treaty establishing the European Economic Community.
The conditions for applying
column76: to those departments
column77: the provisions of the Agreement relating to other fields shall be decided at a later date by agreement between the Contracting Parties.\nArticle 18\nAnnexes I and II
column78:
the lists appearing therein and the Protocol shall form an integral part of the Agreement.
Article 19
This Agreement shall enter into force on the first day of the month following the day on which the Contracting Parties notify each other of the completion of the procedures necessary to that end.
Article 20
This Agreement is drawn up in two copies in the Dutch
column79: French
column80: German
column81: Italian and Spanish languages
column82: each of these texts being authentic.\nIn witness whereof
column83: the undersigned plenipotentiaries have signed this Agreement.\nDone at Luxembourg this twenty-ninth day of June in the year one thousand nine hundred and seventy.\nFor the Council of the European Communities
column84:
Pierre HARMEL
Jean REY
Subject to the reservation that the European Economic Community shall not be finally bound until notification has been given to the other Contracting Party of completion of the procedures required by the Treaty establishing the European Economic Community.
For the Spanish Head of State
column85:
Gregorio LOPEZ BRAVO
ANNEX I
On the implementation of Article 2 (1) of the Agreement
Article 1
Imports into the Community of products originating in Spain which are covered by the provisions of this Annex
column86: including the products set out in Lists A and B but excluding those listed in Articles 3 and 10
column87: shall be admitted without quantitative restrictions.\nArticle 2\nSubject to the special provisions of Articles 3
column88: 4 and 5
column89: the customs duties applicable to imports into the Community of products originating in Spain not listed in Annex II to the Treaty establishing the European Economic Community and not included in Lists A and B shall be those in the Common Customs Tariff reduced by the following percentages and in accordance with the following timetable:\nArticle 3\n1. Imports into the Community of the following products refined in Spain shall qualify for the reductions in customs duties provided for in Article 2
column90: within an annual Community tariff quota of 1 200 000 metric tons.\n2. The Community shall be entitled to modify the arrangements laid down in this Article:\n- when a common definition of orgin is adopted for petroleum products from third States or Associated countries
column91: \n- when decisions are taken in the context of a common commercial policy
column92:
- when a common energy policy is established.
In that event the Community shall ensure that the imports referred to in paragraph 1 are accorded advantages equivalent to those laid down in this Article.
3. Consultations may take place in the Joint Committee on the measures taken in pursuance of paragraph 2.
4. Subject to paragraphs 1 and 2
column93: the provisions of this Agreement shall not affect the regulations applied to imports of petroleum products.\nArticle 4\nImports into the Community of the following products originating in Spain shall qualify for the reductions in customs duties provided for in Article 2
column94: within an annual Community tariff quota of 1 800 metric tons:\nArticle 5\n1. Imports into the Community of products listed in paragraph 2
column95: originating in Spain
column96: shall be subject to the duties in the Common Customs Tariff
column97:
reduced by the following percentages and in accordance with the following timetable:
2. The List referred to in paragraph 1 is as follows:
Article 6
Imports into the Community of the products specified in Articles 2
column99:
4 and 5 originating in Spain shall be exempt from charges having an effect equivalent to customs duties.
Article 7
1. Imports into the Community of the following products originating in Spain shall be subject to customs duties equal to 60 % of the duties in the Customs Tariff.
2. During the period of application of reference prices
column100: paragraph 1 shall apply on condition that on the internal Community market the prices of citrus fruit imported from Spain are
column101: after customs clearance and allowance for the conversion factors operative for the various classes of citrus fruit and after deduction of transport costs and import charges other than customs duties
column102: not less than the reference prices for the period in question
column103: plus the incidence of the Common Customs Tariff on those reference prices and a fixed amount of 1.20 units of account per 100 kg.\n3. The transport costs and import other than customs duties referred to in paragraph 2 shall be those laid down for calculating the entry prices referred to in Regulation No 23 on the progressive establishment of a common organization of the market in fruit and vegetables.\nHowever
column104: the Community shall be entitled to calculate the amount to be deducted in respect of import charges other than customs duties referred to in paragraph 2 in such a way as to avoid difficulties which may arise from the incidence of those charges on entry prices
column105: depending on origin.\n4. The provisions of Article 11 of Regulation No 23 shall continue to apply.\n5. Where the advantages accruing from the provisions of paragraph 1 would or could be jeopardized by reason of abnormal conditions of competition
column106: consultations may be held in the Joint Committee on the problems arising from such situation.\nArticle 8\n1. The Community shall take all measures necessary to ensure that the levy on imports into the Community of olive oil other than refined olive oil
column107: falling within subheading No 15.07 A II of the Common Customs Tariff
column108: wholly produced in Spain and transported direct from that country to the Community
column109: is the import levy calculated in accordance with the provisions of Article 13 of Regulation No 136/66/EEC on the establishment of a common organization of the market in oils and fats
column110: less 0.50 units of account per 100 kg.\n2. Additionally and on condition that Spain applies a special export charge reflected in the import price
column111: the Community shall reduce the amount of the levy
column112: calculated in accordance with paragraph 1
column113:
by an amount equal to that of the charge paid but not exceeding 4 units of account per 100 kg.
Each Contracting Party shall take the measures necessary for implementation of this paragraph.
3. Consultations on the operation of the arrangements provided for in this Article may be held in the Joint Committee.
Article 9
1. Imports into the Community of the following products originating in Spain shall be subject to customs duties equal to 30 % of the duties in the Common Customs Tariff
column114:
within an annual Community tariff quota of 200 metric tons:
2. Imports into the Community of the following products originating in Spain shall be admitted free of customs duties within an annual Community tariff quota of 1 700 metric tons:
Article 10
Imports into the Community of the following products originating in Spain shall be subject to the duties in the Common Customs Tariff reduced by the percentages shown below:
Article 11
Imports into the Community of the following products originating in Spain shall be subject to the duties in the Common Customs Tariff reduced by tire percentages shown below:
Article 12
1. The rates of duty in the Common Customs Tariff to be used for calculation of the reduced duties referred to in Articles 2
column121: 10 and 11 shall be those actually applied at any given time in respect of third States.\n2. The reduced duties
column122: calculated in accordance with Articles 2
column129: 10 and 11 shall be rounded off the first place of decimals.\nArticle 13\nIf the Agreement does not enter into force at the beginning of a calendar year
column130: the quotas referred to in Articles 3
column131: 4 and 9 shall be opened pro rata temporis:\n- beginning in the first year
column132: on the date of entry into force of this Agreement
column133: \n- in the last year
column134: ending on the date of expiry of the first stage.\nArticle 14\nShould regulations be introduced for the specific purpose of implementing the common agricultural policy
column135: the Community shall be entitled to modify the arrangements laid down in this Annex with a view
column136: in particular
column137: to preventing certain distortions of competition or substitutions in respect of products covered by this Annex but not coming under Annex II to the Treaty establishing the European Economic Community.\nWhen introducing such regulations and modifying such arrangements
column138: the Community shall have regard to the interests of Spain.\n2. Should Community regulations be introduced in respect of products covered by this Annex and coming under Annex II to the Treaty establishing the European Economic Community
column139: the Community shall be entitled to modify the arrangements laid down in this Annex.\nWhen introducing such regulations
column140: and amending such arrangements
column141: the Community shall have regard to the interests of Spain.\n3. Should Community regulations be amended in respect of products covered by this Annex and coming under Annex II to the Treaty establishing the European Economic Community
column142: the Community shall be entitled to modify the arrangements laid down in this Annex.\nWhen modifying such arrangements
column143:
the Community shall grant in respect of imports originating in Spain an advantage comparable to that provided for this Annex.
4. The application of this Article may be the subject of consultations in the Joint Committee.
Article 15
Products originating in Spain listed in this Annex may not be given more favourable treatment than that accorded under the Treaty establishing the European Economic Community by the Member States to one another.
Article 16
The Community shall apply
column144: in respect of Spain
column145: the Convention on the Valuation of Goods for Customs  Purposes signed at Brussels on 15 December 1950 and the International Convention for the Simplification of Customs and other Formalities concluded at Geneva on 3 November 1923.\nLIST A\nProducts which
column146: as a result of implementation of the common agricultural policy
column147: are subject to special rules on importation into the Community
column148:
and to which the provisions of Article 2 do not apply
LIST B
Referred to in Article 2
ANNEX II
On the implementation of Article 2 (2) of the Agreement
Article 1
The customs duties and charges having equivalent effect applicable to imports into Spain of products originating in the Community and included in Lists A
column149: B and C shall be those in the Spanish Customs Tariff
column150:
reduced by the following percentages and in accordance with the following timetable:
Article 2
1. The rates of duty in the Spanish Customs Tariff to be used for calculation of the reduced duties listed in Article 1 shall be those actually applied at the time in respect of third States. The reduced rates shall be rounded-off to the first place of decimals.
2. Where duties in the Spanish Customs Tariff or charges having equivalent effect are introduced or modified
column151: the percentage reductions granted to the Community under Article 1 shall remain unchanged.\nArticle 3\n1. Notwithstanding Articles 1 and 2 and on condition that protective measures are necessary for its industrialization and development
column152: Spain may introduce
column153: increase or reintroduce ad valorem customs duties not exceeding 15 % or
column154: in certain special and exceptional cases
column155: 20 %. Such measures may be applied up to an amount not exceeding 5 % of the total value of Spanish imports from the Community for the year 1968.\n2. These measures may be taken only if necessary for the protection of
column156: or for furthering the development of
column157: a new processing industry not existing in Spain at the date of entry into force of the Agreement ; they may be applied only in respect of a specific line of production.\n3. Twelve months after the introduction
column158:
increase or reintroduction of customs duties Spain shall make tariff reductions of 5 % per year in respect of imports originating in the Community.
4. The measures referred to in paragraph 1 shall be taken after consultations in the Joint Committee. These consultations shall take place with the minimum of delay.
Article 4
1. Spain shall refrain from introducing any new quantitative restrictions on imports of products originating in the Community other than those listed in Annex II to the Treaty establishing the European Economic Community.
This obligation shall apply
column159: however
column160: only to 80 % of the value of total imports of those products
column161: calculated on the basis of the average for the years 1966
column163: and 1968.\n2. If Spain introduces or reintroduces
column164: in accordance with paragraph 1
column165:
quantitative restrictions on imports of the products referred to in paragraph 1 it shall open to the Community quotas for such products originating in the Community. Each of these quotas shall be not less than 75 % of Spanish imports of the products covered thereby during the year preceding the introduction or reintroduction of the quantitative restrictions.
These quotas shall be subject to the provisions of Article 5.
Article 5
1. For products originating in the Community included in List D
column166: Spain shall open quotas for the values shown in the fourth column of that list.\n2. If the Agreement does not enter into force at the beginning of a calendar year
column167: the quotas referred to in this Article shall be opened pro rata temporis:\n- beginning

TITLE II
Provisions on the organisation of methods of administrative cooperation
Article 6
Originating products within the meaning of this Protocol shall be accepted in the importing Member State or in Spain as coming under the Agreement on production of a movement certificate AE1 endorsed by the customs authorities of Spain or the Member State.
However
column240: products sent in postal packets (including parcels)
column241: provided each packet contains only \"originating products\" of a value not exceeding 1 000 units of account shall be accepted in Spain or in the Member State as coming under the Agreement
column242:
on production of form AE2.
Article 7
Movement certificate AE1 shall be endorsed only upon written application by the exporter made out on the form prescribed for this purpose.
Article 8
Movement certificate AE1 shall be endorsed by the customs authorities of the exporting State at the time of exportation of the goods to which it relates. It shall be made available to the exporter as soon as exportation has been actually effected or ensured.
Exceptionally
column243: movement certificate AE1 may be endorsed after exportation of the goods to which it relates if
column245:
it was not produced at the time of exportation. In that case a special note shall be added explaining the circumstances in which it was endorsed.
Movement certificate AE1 may be endorsed only where it can serve as documentary evidence for the application of the preferential treatment provided for by the Agreement.
Article 9
Movement certificate AE1 must be submitted to the customs office of the importing State where the goods are presented within two months of the date of endorsement by the customs authorities of the exporting State.
Article 10
Movement certificate AE1 shall be made out in the form shown in the Annex to this Protocol. It shall be in one of the official languages of the European Economic Community and shall comply with the internal laws of the exporting country. It shall be typed or handwritten; if the latter
column246: it shall be in ink in block letters.\nThe size of the certificate shall be 21 x 29.7 cm. The paper used shall be sized writing paper containing no mechanical pulp
column247: and weighing not less than 64 g per sq m; if air mail paper is used
column248: the weight shall be between 25 and 30 g per sq m. It shall have a printed green guilloche pattern background such as to reveal any falsification by mechanical or chemical means.\nA band consisting of three blue stripes
column250:
shall be printed diagonally across the front of each certificate from the lower left to the top right corner.
The Member States and Spain may themselves print the certificates or may entrust the work to printers authorized by them. In the latter case reference to that authorization must appear on each form. Each certificate must bear the distinguishing mark of the authorized printers and an identifying serial number.
Article 11
The movement certificate shall be submitted to the customs authorities of the importing State in accordance with its procedural requirements. Those authorities shall have the right to require a translation of it. They may require the import declaration to be supplemented by a statement by the importer that the goods satisfy the conditions required by the Agreement.
Article 12
Form AE2
column251: a specimen of which is annexed to this Protocol
column252: shall be completed by the exporter. It shall be in one of the official languages of the European Economic Community and shall comply with the internal laws of the exporting country. It shall be typed or handwritten; if the latter
column253: it shall be in ink in block letters.\nForm AE2 shall consist of two parts
column254: each measuring 21 x 14.8 cm. The paper used shall be white sized writing paper containing no mechanical pulp
column255: and weighing not less than 64 g per sq m. A band consisting of three blue stripes
column257: shall be printed diagonally across the front of each part from the lower left to the top right corner.\nForm AE2 may be perforated by machine so that the two parts may be detached
column258:
as also the label which is to be affixed to the consignment. The reverse of that part may be gummed.
The Member States and Spain may themselves print the forms or may entrust the work to printers authorized by them. In the latter case reference to that authorization must appear on each form. Each part must bear the distinguishing mark of the authorized printers and an identifying serial number.
Article 13
A form AE2 shall be made out for each postal packet. After completing and signing both parts the exporter shall place his declaration (part 1) inside the packet and affix the label from part 2 of form AE2 to the outer wrapping.
These provisions shall not exempt exporters from compliance with the other formalities laid down by customs or postal regulations.
Article 14
Unless improper use is suspected

column263: without requiring the production of movement certificate AE1 or the completion of a form AE2

column265: if these goods serve no commercial purpose and they are declared to comply with the conditions required for the application of these provisions and the accuracy of this declaration is not in doubt.\n2. Imports shall be considered as serving no commercial purpose if they are occasional and consist exclusively of goods for the personal or family use of the addresses or travellers ; the nature or quantity of such goods must not be such as might indicate that they are being imported for commercial reasons. The arrangements for such reviews will be determined in accordance with the questions to be examined in each case."

title: Additional Agreement to the Agreement concerning products of the clock and watch industry between the European Economic Community and its Member States and the Swiss Confederation
eurovoc_descriptors: agreement (EU);clock and watch industry;EC agreement;Switzerland;technical regulations
text:
'"EUR-Lex - 21970A0720(01) - EN














Avis juridique important










|








21970A0720(01)




Additional Agreement to the Agreement concerning products of the clock and watch industry between the European Economic Community and its Member States and the Swiss Confederation  






Official Journal L 118
column15:
30/04/1974 P. 0012 - 0017
 Finnish special edition: Chapter 11 Volume 2 P. 0004 
 Swedish special edition: Chapter 11 Volume 2 P. 0004 
 Spanish special edition: Chapter 11 Volume 5 P. 0110 
 Portuguese special edition Chapter 11 Volume 5 P. 0110 
 












ADDITIONAL AGREEMENT to the Agreement concerning products of the clock and watch industry between the European Economic Community and its Member States and the Swiss Confederation
THE COUNCIL OF THE EUROPEAN COMMUNITIES
column17: and\nTHE SWISS FEDERAL COUNCIL
column20: at the same time as this Agreement comes into force
column21: of the rationalization grants accorded by Ebauches SA and ASUAG and of the simultaneous abolition of the quota referred to in point B 3 (b) of the abovementioned Agreement
column22:
(1)The Agreement has been drawn up in the French language only.
HAVE AGREED as follows:
Article 1
The tariff reductions specified in Articles 1 and 5 of the Agreement of 30 June 1967 shall enter into force at the same time as this Agreement.
Article 2
In order that a watch with a movement of Swiss manufacture as regards not less than 50 % of the value of all the constituent parts including the cost of assembly by virtue of Article 2 (2) (b) of the ordinance of the Swiss Federal Council of 23 December 1971 governing the use of the description "Swiss" for watches can be considered to be Swiss
column23: a certification procedure shall be established between Switzerland and the Community in accordance with the following rules:\n1. Rough watch movements manufactured in the Community and listed in the Annex to the Agreement
column24: and the regulating organs and other constituent watch-movement parts manufactured in the Community and complementary to rough movements of Swiss or Community manufacture
column25:
shall be considered to be equivalent in quality to rough movements and parts of Swiss manufacture with comparable technical characteristics. It shall be understood that watches and watch movements assembled from these rough movements and parts must satisfy the statutory technical control requirements in Switzerland.
2. The list specified in paragraph 1 of this Article of rough movements manufactured in the Community shall be brought up to date regularly in the following manner:
(a) Applications for new calibres of rough movements to be entered on the list shall be sent to the Chambre suisse de l''horlogerie by the associations of clock and watch makers in the Community or any manufacturer of rough movements established in the Community. applications shall be accompanied by a technical description of the calibre of the rough movements. The Chambre suisse de l''horlogerie shall enter the new calibre or calibres on the said list forthwith.
Should the entry be requested for a calibre of rough movements which has already been used in Switzerland and has failed to pass the statutory control in Switzerland
column26: the Chambre suisse de l''horlogerie may contest the entry. In this event
column27: the applicant may resort to the procedure provided for in paragraph 3 of this Article.\n(b) The withdrawal of calibres of rough movements appearing on the list shall be communicated to the Chambre suisse de l''horlogerie by the associations of the clock and watch makers in the Community or by the manufacturer who had previously applied for the calibre to be entered on the list.\n(c) Should the statutory technical-control requirements in Switzerland not be satisfied
column28: the Chambre suisse d''horlogerie may request that the calibres of rough movements concerned be struck off the list and shall notify the party concerned of this request. In the event of a disagreement
column29: the party concerned may
column30: within two months
column31: resort to the procedure provided for in paragraph 3 of this Article.\n(d) All applications for amendments to the list
column32: in accordance with subparagraphs (a)
column33: (b) and (c) above
column34: shall be notified to the Joint Committee by the Chambre suisse de l''horlogerie forthwith.\n3. In the event of a dispute about the equivalence of quality
column35: the matter shall be referred forthwith by any interested party to the Joint Committee provided for in Article 9 of the Agreement of 30 June 1967.\nThe first party so to decide shall
column36: on its own initiative
column37: seek a joint expert opinion from the institute for official quality control in the Swiss clock and watch industry and a corresponding qualified institute in the Community nominated by the Community interested party.\nThe institutes shall have three months in which to give the expert opinion requested.\nFor the purposes of giving this expert opinion
column38: the institutes shall agree between themselves to take two sufficiently representative batches of watches or watch movements
column39: each normally containing not more than 50 watches or watch movements
column40: one in a Swiss enterprise
column41: the other in a Community enterprise.\nAfter testing these batches in accordance with the technical control standards statutory in Switzerland
column42:
the institutes shall compare their results and shall jointly draw up a report for the Joint Committee containing their conclusions and any proposals they may have.
The Joint Committee shall consider this report at its following meeting.
Article 3
The Agreement and the annexed list shall be published in the official journals of the contracting parties and shall be communicated to the watch and clock manufacturers by the trade associations concerned.
Changes in the annexed list shall be published and communicated in the same manner.
Every three years at least
column43: beginning from the entry into force of the Agreement
column44:
the Joint Committee shall review the list to take into account any items which have in the meantime been entered on or struck off the list. The new list shall be published and communicated in the same manner.
Any further information can be obtained from the trade associations concerned.
Article 4
Either Contracting Party may denounce the Agreement by giving 12 months''notice.
Article 5
The Agreement shall be concluded and ratified by the Contracting Parties in accordance with their own procedures.
The Agreement shall enter into force on 1 January 1973 provided that the Contracting Parties have exchanged their instruments of ratification by that date.
Should the instruments of ratification be exchanged between 1 January and 30 November 1973
column45: the Agreement shall enter into force on the first day of the second month following that exchange.\nANNEX\nList specified in Article 2"'

column25: \nI have the honour to acknowledge receipt of your letter of... worded as follows:\n\"I have the honour to refer to the request of your Government that the tariff quota
column26: opened on 1 September 1969 for a number of handicraft products
column27: should be extended by the Community to a number of other products.\nAfter a detailed study of that request

T. SWAMINATHAN
