title: 'Agreement between the European Economic Community and the Swiss Confederation - Protocol No 1 concerning the treatment applicable to certain products - Protocol No 2 concerning products subject to special arrangements to take account of differences in the cost of agricultural products incorporated therein - Protocol No 3 concerning the definition of the concept of ''originating products'' and methods of administrative cooperation - Protocol No 4 concerning certain provisions relating to Ireland - Protocol No 5 concerning the treatment that may be applied by Switzerland to imports of certain products subject to the scheme for building up compulsory reserves - Final Act - Joint Declarations - Unilateral Declarations'

THE EUROPEAN ECONOMIC COMMUNITY

(ii) which are specified in Protocol No 2

column47: while observing the conditions of Article 18
column48: duties corresponding to the fiscal element contained in customs duties on imports of products specified in Annex II.\nThe Joint Committee provided for in Article 29 shall examine whether the conditions set out in the preceding subparagraph are being met

particularly where a change has been made in the amount of the fiscal element.
The Joint Committee shall examine the position with a view to the conversion of such duties into internal charges before 1 January 1980 or before any other date which it might determine in the light of circumstances.

with rounding to the fourth decimal place.
Article 6
1. No new charge having an effect equivalent to a customs duty on imports shall be introduced in trade between the Community and Switzerland.
2. Charges having an effect equivalent to customs duties on imports introduced on or after 1 January 1972 in trade between the Community and Switzerland shall be abolished upon the entry into force of the Agreement.
Any charge having an effect equivalent to a customs duty on imports
column60:
the rate of which on 31 December 1972 is higher than that actually applied on 1 January 1972 shall be reduced to the latter rate upon the entry into force of the Agreement.
3. Charges having an effect equivalent to customs duties on imports shall be progressively abolished in accordance with the following timetable:
(a) by 1 January 1974 at the latest each charge shall be reduced to 60 % of the rate applied on 1 January 1972;
(b) three further reductions of 20 % each shall be made on:
1 January 1975
column61: \n1 January 1976
column62:
1 July 1977.
Article 7
1. No customs duty on exports or charge having equivalent effect shall be introduced in trade between the Community and Switzerland.
Customs duties on exports and charges having equivalent effect shall be abolished not later than 1 January 1974.
2. In the case of products listed in Annex HI
column63: the Contracting Parties may take
column64: in such manner as they shall determine
column65:
the measures they consider necessary to implement their supply policies.
Article 8
Protocol No 1 lays down the tariff treatment and arrangements applicable to certain products.
Article 9
Protocol No 2 lays down the tariff treatment and arrangements applicable to certain goods obtained by processing agricultural products.
Article 10
1. In the event of specific rules being established as or of any alteration of the current rules the Contracting Party in question may adapt the arrangements resulting from this Agreement in respect of the products which are the subject of those rules or alterations.
2. In such cases the Contracting Party in question shall take due account of the interests of the other Contracting Party. To this end the Contracting Parties may consult each other within the Joint Committee.
Article 11
Protocol No 3 lays down the rules of origin.
Article 12
A Contracting Party which is considering the reduction of the effective level of its duties or charges having equivalent effect applicable to third countries benefiting from most favoured-nation treatment
column66: or which is considering the suspension of their application

column68: as far as may be practicable
column69:
notify the Joint Committee not less than thirty days before such reduction or suspension comes into effect. It shall take note of any representations by the other Contracting Party regarding any distortions which might result therefrom.
Article 13
1. No new quantitative restriction on imports or measures having equivalent effect shall be introduced in trade between the Community and Switzerland.
2. Quantitative restrictions on imports shall be abolished on 1 January 1973 and any measures having an effect equivalent to quantitative restrictions on imports shall be abolished not later than 1 January 1975.
Article 14
1. The Community reserves the right to modify the arrangements applicable to the petroleum products falling within heading Nos 27.10

column76: which shall meet under the conditions set out in Article 31.\n2. Switzerland reserves the right to take similar action should it be faced with like situations.\n3. Subject to paragraphs 1 and 2
column77: the Agreement shall not prejudice the non-tariff rules applied to imports of petroleum products.\nArticle 15\n1. The Contracting Parties declare their readiness to foster
column78: so far as their agricultural policies allow

Article 16
From 1 July 1977 products originating in Switzerland may not enjoy more favourable treatment when imported into the Community than that applied by the Member States of the Community between themselves.
Article 17
The Agreement shall not preclude the maintenance or establishment of customs unions
column83: free trade areas or arrangements for frontier trade

column85: in particular the provisions concerning rules of origin.\nArticle 18\nThe Contracting Parties shall refrain from any measure or practice of an internal fiscal nature establishing
column86: whether directly or indirectly

discrimination between the products of one Contracting Party and like products originating in the territory of the other Contracting Party.
Products exported to the territory of one of the Contracting Parties may not benefit from repayment of internal taxation in excess of the amount of direct or indirect taxation imposed on them.
Article 19
Payments relating to trade in goods and the transfer of such payments to the Member State of the Community in which the creditor is resident or to Switzerland shall be free from any restrictions.
The Contracting Parties shall refrain from any exchange or administrative restrictions on the grant
column88: repayment or acceptance of short- and medium-term credits covering commercial transactions in which a resident participates.\nArticle 20\nThe Agreement shall not preclude prohibitions or restrictions on imports

Article 21

Article 22
1. The Contracting Parties shall refrain from any measure likely to jeopardize the fulfilment of the objectives of the Agreement.

Article 24

the Contracting Party concerned may take appropriate measures under the conditions and in accordance with the procedures laid down in Article 27.

If one of the Contracting Parties finds that dumping is taking place in trade with the other Contracting Party

This Agreement will be approved by the Contracting Parties in accordance with their own procedures.
It shall enter into force on 1 January 1973 provided that the Contracting Parties have notified each other before that date that the procedures necessary to this end have been completed.
After this date this Agreement shall enter into force on the first day of the second month following such notification. The final date for such notification shall be 30 November 1973.
The provisions applicable on 1 April 1973 shall be applied upon the entry into force of this Agreement if it enters into force after that date.

Article 10
1. A movement certificate shall be issued by the Customs authorities of the exporting State when the goods to which at relates are exported. It shall be made available to the exporter as soon as actual exportation has been effected or ensured.
In exceptional circumstances a movement certificate may also be issued after exportation of the goods to which it relates if it was not issued at the time of exportation because of errors or involuntary omissions or special circumstances. In this case
column820:
the certificate shall bear a special reference to the conditions in which it was issued.
A movement certificate may be issued only where it can serve as the documentary evidence required for the purpose of implementing the preferential treatment provided for in the Agreement.
2. A movement certificate issued under the conditions laid down in Article 8(2) or (4) must bear
references to the movement certificate or certificates issued earlier upon presentation of which it is issued.
3. Applications for movement certificates and for certificates referred to in paragraph 2

--------------------------------------------------
DECLARATIONS
Joint declaration by the Contracting Parties concerning Article 4(3) of Protocol No 1
The Contracting Parties acknowledge that the Exchange of Letters of 30 June 1967 between the European Economic Community and the Swiss Confederation relating to the Clock and Watch Agreement shall remain valid and may be invoked if the provisions of this Agreement should cease to apply to products falling within Chapter 91 of the Brusse.s Nomenclature in accordance with Article 4(3) of Protocol No 1.
Joint declaration by the Contracting Parties concerning transport of goods in transit
The Contracting Parties consider that it is in the common interest that the rates and conditions for the transport of goods
(i) to and from the Community involving transit through Swiss territory; or
(ii) to and from Switzerland involving transit through Community territory
column1914:
should not involve any discrimination or distortion based on the country of destination of the goods concerned or on the country from which they come and likely to have an adverse effect on the proper functioning of the free movement of these goods.
Declaration concerning workers
In view of the importance of the activities in Switzerland of workers who are nationals of Member States in the context of their reciprocal relations
column1915: the Contracting Parties emphasize the common interest they have in matters relating to labour. In this connecion
column1916: they note with satisfaction the signature in Rome on 22 June 1972 of a document recording the results of the work of the Italian-Swiss Joint Committee.\nThe Contracting Parties have noted that in the course of that Committee''s work important principles were formulated and substantial progress was thereby achieved
column1917: the stabilization policy adopted by the Swiss authorities being fully observed; appropriate provisions were adopted to achieve further progress as soon as possible. They noted also that this stabilization goes hand in hand with the implementation of a policy which is designed to introduce progressively as uniform a labour market as possible.\nThe Contracting Parties are determined
column1919: to promote the introduction of the most satisfactory solutions to these questions of common interest. They declare their willingness to examine together any problems which may arise concerning their workers.\nDeclaration by the European Economic Community concerning the regional application of certain provisions of the Agreement\nThe European Economic Community declares that the application of any measures it may take under Articles 23
column1922: in accordance with the procedure and under the arrangements set out in Article 27
column1924: may be limited to one of its regions by virtue of Community rules.\nDeclaration by the European Economic Community concerning Article 23(1) of the Agreement\nThe European Economic Community declares that in the context of the autonomous implementation of Article 23(1) of the Agreement which is incumbent on the Contracting Parties
column1925: it will assess any practices contrary to that Article on the basis of criteria arising from the application of the rules of Articles 85
column1927: 90 and 92 of the Treaty establishing the European Economic Community.\n--------------------------------------------------"'

column16:
'"L_1972300EN.01028301.xml






















31.12.1972   






EN






Official Journal of the European Communities






L 300/283












ADDITIONAL AGREEMENT


Concerning the validity
column17: for the Principality of Liechtenstein
column18:
of the Agreement between the European Economic Community and the Swiss Confederation of 22 July 1972


THE EUROPEAN ECONOMIC COMMUNITY
column19: THE SWISS CONFEDERATION
column20: THE PRINCIPALITY OF LIECHTENSTEIN
column21:
Whereas by the Treaty of 29 March 1923 the Principality of Liechtenstein and Switzerland constitute a customs union and whereas that Treaty does not confer validity for the Principality of Liechtenstein on all the provisions of the Agreement between the European Economic Community and the Swiss Confederation signed on 22 July 1972;


Whereas the Principality of Liechtenstein has expressed the desire that all the provisions of that Agreement should apply to it
column22:
HAVE AGREED AS FOLLOWS:


Article 1


The Agreement between the European Economic Community and the Swiss Confederation signed on 22 July 1972 shall likewise apply to the Principality of Liechtenstein.


Article 2


For the purpose of implementing the Agreement referred to in Article 1 and without modifying its bilateral nature between the Community and Switzerland
column23:
the Principality of Liechtenstein may cause its interests to be represented through a representative within the Swiss delegation to the Joint Committee.


Article 3


This additional Agreement will be approved by Switzerland
column24:
the Principality of Liechtenstein and the Community in accordance with their own procedures. It shall enter into force at the same time as the Agreement referred to in Article 1 and shall continue to apply for so long as the Treaty of 29 March 1923 remains in force.

title: 'Agreement between the European Economic Community and the Republic of Iceland - Protocol No 1 concerning the treatment applicable to certain products - Protocol No 2 concerning products subject to special arrangements to take account of differences in the cost of agricultural products incorporated therein - Protocol No 3 concerning the definition of the concept of ''originating products'' and methods of administrative cooperation - Protocol No 4 concerning quantitative restrictions which Iceland may retain - Protocol No 5 concerning certain provisions relating to Ireland - Protocol No 6 concerning the special provisions applicable to imports of certain fish products into the Community - Final Act - Declarations by the Community'

text:
'"EUR-Lex - 21972A0722(05) - EN














Avis juridique important










|








21972A0722(05)




Agreement between the European Economic Community and the Republic of Iceland - Protocol No 1 concerning the treatment applicable to certain products - Protocol No 2 concerning products subject to special arrangements to take account of differences in the cost of agricultural products incorporated therein - Protocol No 3 concerning the definition of the concept of ''originating products'' and methods of administrative cooperation - Protocol No 4 concerning quantitative restrictions which Iceland may retain - Protocol No 5 concerning certain provisions relating to Ireland - Protocol No 6 concerning the special provisions applicable to imports of certain fish products into the Community - Final Act - Declarations by the Community  






Official Journal L 301
column15:
31/12/1972 P. 0002 - 0085
 Finnish special edition: Chapter 2 Volume 1 P. 0133 
 Swedish special edition: Chapter 2 Volume 1 P. 0133

 English special edition: Series I Chapter 1972(31.12)L301 P. 0004

 Spanish special edition: Chapter 11 Volume 3 P. 0006 
 Portuguese special edition Chapter 11 Volume 3 P. 0006 
 












REGULATION (EEC) No 2842/72 OF THE COUNCIL  of 19 December 1972  concluding an Agreement between the European Economic Community and the Republic of Iceland and adopting provisions for its implementation
  THE COUNCIL OF THE EUROPEAN COMMUNITIES
column16: \n Having regard to the Treaty establishing the European Economic Community
column17: and in particular Article 113 thereof
column18: \n Having regard to the proposal from the Commission
column19: \n Whereas the Agreement between the European Economic Community and the Republic of Iceland signed in Brussels on 22 July 1972 should be concluded and the Declarations annexed to the Final Act
column20: likewise signed in Brussels on 22 July 1972
column21: should be adopted; \n Whereas
column22: since the Agreement establishes a Joint Committee
column23:
representatives of the Community on this Committee should be appointed; 
 HAS ADOPTED THIS REGULATION:
 
   Article 1
 The Agreement between the European Economic Community and the Republic of Iceland
column24: the Annexes and Protocols thereto
column25: and the Declarations annexed to the Final Act are hereby concluded
column26:
adopted and confirmed on behalf of the Community. 
 The texts of the Agreement and of the Final Act are annexed to this Regulation. 
 
 Article 2
 Pursuant to Article 37 of the Agreement
column27:
the President of the Council of the European Communities shall give notification that the procedures necessary for the entry into force of the Agreement have been completed on the part of the Community. 
 
 Article 3
 Within the Joint Committee provided in Article 30 of the Agreement
column28: the Community shall be represented by the Commission
column29:
assisted by the representatives of the Member States. 
 
 Article 4
 This Regulation shall enter into force on the third day following its publication in the Official Journal of the European Communities.
 
 
   This Regulation is binding in its entirety and directly applicable in all Member States. 
 Done at Brussels
column30:
19 December 1972. 
 For the Council 
 The President 
 T. WESTERTERP   
 
    AGREEMENT  between the European Economic Community and the Republic of Iceland 
 
 THE EUROPEAN ECONOMIC COMMUNITY
column31: \n of the one part
column32: and \n THE REPUBLIC OF ICELAND
column33: \n of the other part
column34: \n DESIRING to consolidate and to extend
column35: upon the enlargement of the European Economic Community
column36: the economic relations existing between the Community and Iceland and to ensure
column37: with due regard for fair conditions of competition
column38: the harmonious development of their commerce for the purpose of contributing to the work of constructing Europe
column39: \n RESOLVED to this end to eliminate progressively the obstacles to substantially all their trade
column40: in accordance with the provisions of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade concerning the establishment of free trade areas
column41: \n DECLARING their readiness to examine
column42: in the light of any relevant factor
column43: and in particular of developments in the Community
column44: the possibility of developing and deepening their relations where it would appear to be useful in the interests of their economies to extend them to fields not covered by this Agreement
column45: \n HAVE DECIDED
column46: in pursuit of these objectives and considering that no provision of this Agreement may be interpreted as exempting the Contracting Parties from the obligations which are incumbent upon them under other international agreements
column47:
TO CONCLUDE THIS AGREEMENT:
 
   Article 1
 The aim of this Agreement is:    (a) to promote through the expansion of reciprocal trade the harmonious development of economic relations between the European Economic Community and the Republic of Iceland and thus to foster in the Community and in Iceland the advance of economic activity
column48: the improvement of living and employment conditions
column49: and increased productivity and financial stability
column50: \n      (b) to provide fair conditions of competition for trade between the Contracting Parties
column51: \n      (c) to contribute in this way
column52: by the removal of barriers to trade
column53:
to the harmonious development and expansion of world trade. 
 
 
 
 Article 2
 The Agreement shall apply to products originating in the Community or Iceland:    (i) which fall within Chapters 25 to 99 of the Brussels Nomenclature
column54: excluding the products listed in Annex I; \n      (ii) which are specified in Protocols Nos 2 and 6
column55:
with due regard to the arrangements provided for in those Protocols. 
 
 
 
 Article 3
 1. No new customs duty on imports shall be introduced in trade between the Community and Iceland. 
 2. The Community as originally constituted and Ireland shall progressively abolish customs duties on imports in accordance with the following timetable:     (a) on 1 April 1973 each duty shall be reduced to 80 % of the basic duty; 
      (b) four further reductions of 20 % each shall be made on: 
 1 January 1974
column56: \n 1 January 1975
column57: \n 1 January 1976
column58:
1 July 1977. 
 
 
 3. The basic duty to which the successive reductions provided for in this Article and in Protocol No 1 are to be applied shall
column59: for each product
column60: be the duty actually applied on 1 January 1972. \n If
column61: after 1 January 1972
column62: any tariff reductions resulting from the tariff agreements concluded as a result of the Trade Conference held in Geneva from 1964 to 1967 become applicable
column63: such reduced duties shall replace the basic duties referred to in the previous subparagraph. \n 4. The reduced duties calculated in accordance with this Article and Protocol No 1 shall be applied rounded to the first decimal place. \n Subject to the application by the Community of Article 39 (5) of the \"Act concerning the Conditions of Accession and the Adjustments to the Treaties\" drawn up and adopted within the Conference between the European Communities and the Kingdom of Denmark
column64: Ireland
column65: the Kingdom of Norway and the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
column66: as regards the specific duties or the specific part of the mixed duties in the Irish Customs Tariff
column67: this Article and Protocol No 1 shall be applied
column68:
with rounding to the fourth decimal place. 
 
 Article 4
 1. On the dates indicated Iceland shall reduce customs duties on imports from the Community as originally constituted and from Ireland to the rates of the various basic duties applicable on 1 March 1970 specified below. >PIC FILE= "T0010677">  
 2. After 1 January 1974 Iceland shall continue to reduce customs duties in respect of Denmark
column69:
Norway and the United Kingdom in accordance with the timetable shown in paragraph 1. 
 
 Article 5
 1. The provisions concerning the progressive abolition of customs duties on imports shall also apply to customs duties of a fiscal nature. 
 The Contracting Parties may replace a customs duty of a fiscal nature or the fiscal element of a customs duty by an internal tax. 
 2. Iceland may temporarily retain
column70: with due regard to the conditions of Article 19
column71: customs duties of a fiscal nature on the products specified in Annex II. \n When production is started in Iceland of a product of like kind to one of those listed in Annex II
column72: the duty to which the latter product is subject must be reduced to the level which would have been reached if that duty had been reduced in accordance with the timetable contained in Article 4 (1) since the entry into force of the Agreement. If in respect of third countries a customs duty lower than the duty of a fiscal nature is introduced
column73: the tariff reductions shall be made on the basis of the former duty. \n Subsequent reductions shall be made in accordance with the timetable laid down in Article 4 (1). \n 3. Denmark
column74: Ireland
column75: Norway and the United Kingdom may retain until 1 January 1976 a customs duty of a fiscal nature or the fiscal element of a customs duty upon implementation of Article 38 of the \"Act concerning the Conditions of Accession and  the Adjustments to the Treaties\" drawn up and adopted within the Conference between the European Communities and the Kingdom of Denmark
column76: Ireland
column77:
the Kingdom of Norway and the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland. 
 
 Article 6
 1. No new charge having an effect equivalent to a customs duty on imports shall be introduced in trade between the Community and Iceland. 
 2. Charges having an effect equivalent to customs duties on imports introduced on or after 1 January 1972 in trade between the Community and Iceland shall be abolished upon the entry into force of the Agreement. 
 Any charge having an effect equivalent to a customs duty on imports
column78: the rate of which on 31 December 1972 is higher than that actually applied on 1 January 1972
column79:
shall be reduced to the latter rate upon the entry into force of the Agreement. 
 3. Charges having an effect equivalent to customs duties on imports shall be progressively abolished in accordance with the following timetable:    (a) by 1 January 1974 at the latest each charge shall be reduced to 60 % of the rate applied on 1 January 1972; 
      (b) three further reductions of 20 % each shall be made on: 
 1 January 1975
column80: \n 1 January 1976
column81:
1 July 1977. 
 
 
 
 Article 7
 1. No customs duty on exports or charge having equivalent effect shall be introduced in trade between the Community and Iceland. 
 Customs duties on exports and charges having equivalent effect shall be abolished not later than 1 January 1974. 
 2. Iceland may retain the system of export levy on fish products applicable on 1 January 1972
column82:
which is set out in Annex III. 
 Any changes must not alter the character or aims of the system. The Joint Committee shall be notified beforehand of any changes. 
 
 Article 8
 Protocol No 1 lays down the tariff treatment and arrangements applicable to certain products. 
 
 Article 9
 Protocol No 2 lays down the tariff treatment and arrangements applicable to certain goods obtained by processing agricultural products. 
 
 Article 10
 1. In the event of specific rules being established as a result of the implementation of its agricultural policy or of any alteration of the current rules the Contracting Party in question may adapt the arrangements resulting from this Agreement in respect of the products which are the subject of those rules or alterations. 
 2. In such cases the Contracting Party in question shall take due account of the interests of the other Contracting Party. To this end the Contracting Parties may consult each other within the Joint Committee provided for in Article 30. 
 
 Article 11
 Protocol No 3 lays down the rules of origin. 
 
 Article 12
 A Contracting Party which is considering the reduction of the effective level of its duties or charges having equivalent effect applicable to third countries benefiting from most-favoured-nation treatment
column83: or which is considering the suspension of their application
column84: shall
column85: as far as may be practicable
column86:
notify the Joint Committee not less than thirty days before such reduction or suspension comes into effect. It shall take note of any representations by the other Contracting Party regarding any distortions which might result therefrom. 
 
 Article 13
 1. No new quantitative restriction on imports or measures having equivalent effect shall be introduced in trade between the Community and Iceland. 
 2. The Community shall abolish quantitative restrictions on imports on 1 January 1973 and any measures having an effect equivalent to quantitative restrictions on imports not later than 1 January 1975.  
 Iceland shall abolish quantitative restrictions on imports and any measures having an effect equivalent to quantitative restrictions on imports not later than 1 January 1975. 
 
 Article 14
 1. The Community reserves the right to modify the arrangements applicable to the petroleum products falling within headings Nos 27.10
column89: ex 27.13 (paraffin wax
column90: micro-crystalline wax
column91: or bituminous shale and other mineral waxes) and 27.14 of the Brussels Nomenclature upon adoption of a common definition of origin for petroleum products
column92: upon adoption of decisions under the common commercial policy for the products in question or upon establishment of a common energy policy. \n In this event the Community shall take due account of the interests of Iceland ; to this end it shall inform the Joint Committee
column93: which shall meet under the conditions set out in Article 32. \n 2. Iceland reserves the right to take similar action should it be faced with like situations. \n 3. Subject to paragraphs 1 and 2
column94:
the Agreement shall not prejudice the non-tariff rules applied to imports of petroleum products. 
 
 Article 15
 1. The Contracting Parties declare their readiness to foster
column95: so far as their agricultural policies allow
column96: the harmonious development of trade in agricultural products to which the Agreement does not apply. \n 2. The Contracting Parties shall apply their rules in veterinary
column97: health and plant health matters in a non-discriminatory fashion and shall not introduce any new measures that have the effect of unduly obstructing trade. \n 3. The Contracting Parties shall examine
column98: under the conditions set out in Article 33
column99:
any difficulties that might arise in their trade in agricultural products and shall endeavour to seek appropriate solutions. 
 
 Article 16
 From 1 July 1977 products originating in Iceland may not enjoy more favourable treatment when imported into the Community than that applied by the Member States of the Community between themselves. 
 
 Article 17
 Protocol No 6 lays down the special provisions applicable to imports of certain fish products into the Community. 
 
 Article 18
 The Agreement shall not preclude the maintenance or establishment of customs unions
column100: free trade areas or arrangements for frontier trade
column101: except in so far as they alter the trade arrangements provided for in this Agreement
column102:
in particular the provisions concerning rules of origin. 
 
 Article 19
 The Contracting Parties shall refrain from any measure or practice of an internal fiscal nature establishing
column103: whether directly or indirectly
column104:
discrimination between the products of one Contracting Party and like products originating in the territory of the other Contracting Party. 
 Products exported to the territory of one of the Contracting Parties may not benefit from repayment of internal taxation in excess of the amount of direct or indirect taxation imposed on them. 
 
 Article 20
 Payments relating to trade in goods and the transfer of such payments to the Member State of the Community in which the creditor is resident or to Iceland shall be free from any restrictions. 
 
 Article 21
 The Agreement shall not preclude prohibitions or restrictions on imports
column105: exports or goods in transit justified on grounds of public morality
column106: law and order or public security
column107: the protection of life and health of humans
column108: animals or plants
column109: the protection of national treasures of artistic
column110: historic or archaeological value
column111: the protection of industrial and commercial property
column112: or rules relating to gold or silver. Such prohibitions or restrictions must not
column113: however
column114:
constitute a means of arbitrary discrimination or a disguised restriction on trade between the Contracting Parties. 
 
 Article 22
 Nothing in the Agreement shall prevent a Contracting Party from taking any measures:    (a) which it considers necessary to prevent the disclosure of information contrary to its essential security interests; 
      (b) which relate to trade in arms
column115: munitions or war materials or to research
column116: development or production indispensable for defence purposes
column117:
provided that such measures do not impair the conditions of competition in respect of products not intended for specifically military purposes; 
      (c) which it considers essential to its own security in time of war or serious international tension. 
 
 
 
 Article 23
 1. The Contracting Parties shall refrain from any measure likely to jeopardize the fulfilment of the objectives of the Agreement. 
 2. They shall take any general or specific measures required to fulfil their obligations under the Agreement. 
 If either Contracting Party considers that the other Contracting Party has failed to fulfil an obligation under the Agreement
column118:
it may take appropriate measures under the conditions and in accordance with the procedures laid down in Article 28. 
 
 Article 24
 1. The following are incompatible with the proper functioning of the Agreement in so far as they may affect trade between the Community and Iceland:    (i) all agreements between undertakings
column119: decisions by associations of undertakings and concerted practices between undertakings which have as their object or effect the prevention
column121:
it may take appropriate measures under the conditions and in accordance with the procedures laid down in Article 28. 
 
 Article 25
 Where an increase in imports of a given product is or is likely to be seriously detrimental to any production activity carried on in the territory of one of the Contracting Parties and where this increase is due to:    (i) the partial or total reduction in the importing Contracting Party
column122: as provided for in the Agreement
column123:
of customs duties and charges having equivalent effect levied on the product in question ; and 
      (ii) the fact that the duties or charges having equivalent effect levied by the exporting Contracting Party on imports of raw materials or intermediate products used in the manufacture of the product in question are significantly lower than the corresponding duties or charges levied by the importing Contracting Party; 
 
 
 the Contracting Party concerned may take appropriate measures under the conditions and in accordance with the procedures laid down in Article 28. 
 
 Article 26
 If one of the Contracting Parties finds that dumping is taking place in trade with the other Contracting Party
column124: it may take appropriate measures against this practice in accordance with the Agreement on Implementation of Article VI of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade
column125:
under the conditions and in accordance with the procedures laid down in Article 28. 
 
 Article 27
 If serious disturbances arise in any sector of the economy or if difficulties arise which could bring about serious deterioration in the economic situation  of a region
column126:
the Contracting Party concerned may take appropriate measures under the conditions and in accordance with the procedures laid down in Article 28. 
 
 Article 28
 1. In the event of a Contracting Party subjecting imports of products liable to give rise to the difficulties referred to in Articles 25 and 27 to an administrative procedure
column127: the purpose of which is to provide rapid information on the trend of trade flows
column128: it shall inform the other Contracting Party. \n 2. In the cases specified in Articles 23 to 27
column129: before taking the measures provided for therein or
column130: in cases to which paragraph 3 (d) applies
column131: as soon as possible
column132: the Contracting Party in question shall supply the Joint Committee with all relevant information required for a thorough examination of the situation with a view to seeking a solution acceptable to the Contracting Parties. \n In the selection of measures
column133: priority must be given to those which least disturb the functioning of the Agreement. \n The safeguard measures shall be notified immediately to the Joint Committee and shall be the subject of periodical consultations within the Committee
column134: particularly with a view to their abolition as soon as circumstances permit. \n 3. For the implementation of paragraph 2
column135: the following provisions shall apply:    (a) As regards Article 24
column136: either Contracting Party may refer the matter to the Joint Committee if it considers that a given practice is incompatible with the proper functioning of the Agreement within the meaning of Article 24 (1). \n The Contracting Parties shall provide the Joint Committee with all relevant information and shall give it the assistance it requires in order to examine the case and
column137: where appropriate
column138: to eliminate the practice objected to. \n If the Contracting Party in question fails to put an end to the practice objected to within the period fixed by the Joint Committee
column139: or in the absence of agreement in the Joint Committee within three months of the matter being referred to it
column140: the Contracting Party concerned may adopt any safeguard measures it considers necessary to deal with the serious difficulties resulting from the practices in question ; in particular it may withdraw tariff concessions. \n      (b) As regards Article 25
column141: the difficulties arising from the situation referred to in that Article shall be referred for examination to the Joint Committee which may take any decision needed to put an end to such difficulties. \n If the Joint Committee or the exporting Contracting Party has not taken a decision putting an end to the difficulties within thirty days of the matter being referred
column142: the importing Contracting Party is authorized to levy a compensatory charge on the product imported. \n The compensatory charge shall be calculated according to the incidence on the value of the goods in question of the tariff disparities in respect of the raw materials or intermediate products incorporated therein. \n      (c) As regards Article 26
column143: consultation in the Joint Committee shall take place before the Contracting Party concerned takes the appropriate measures. \n      (d) Where exceptional circumstances requiring immediate action make prior examination impossible
column144: the Contracting Party concerned may
column145: in the situations specified in Articles 25
column146: 26 and 27 and also in the case of export aids having a direct and immediate incidence on trade
column147:
apply forthwith the precautionary measures strictly necessary to remedy the situation. 
 
 
 
 Article 29
 Where one or more Member States of the Community or Iceland is in difficulties or is seriously threatened with difficulties as regards its balance of payments
column148:
the Contracting Party concerned may take the necessary safeguard measures. It shall inform the other Contracting Party forthwith. 
 
 Article 30
 1. A Joint Committee is hereby established which shall be responsible for the administration of the Agreement and shall ensure its proper implementation. For this purpose
column149: it shall make recommendations and take decisions in the cases provided for in the Agreement. These decisions shall be put into effect by the Contracting Parties in accordance with their own rules. \n 2. For the purpose of the proper implementation of the Agreement the Contracting Parties shall exchange information and
column150: at the request of either Party
column151:
shall hold consultations within the Joint Committee.  
 3. The Joint Committee shall adopt its own rules of procedure. 
 
 Article 31
 1. The Joint Committee shall consist of representatives of the Community
column152: on the one hand
column153: and of representatives of Iceland
column154:
on the other. 
 2. The Joint Committee shall act by mutual agreement. 
 
 Article 32
 1. Each Contracting Party shall preside in turn over the Joint Committee
column155: in accordance with the arrangements to be laid down in its rules of procedure. \n 2. The Chairman shall convene meetings of the Joint Committee at least once a year in order to review the general functioning of the Agreement. \n The Joint Committee shall
column156: in addition
column157: meet whenever special circumstances so require
column158: at the request of either Contracting Party
column159:
in accordance with the conditions to be laid down in its rules of procedure. 
 3. The Joint Committee may decide to set up any working party that can assist it in carrying out its duties. 
 
 Article 33
 1. Where a Contracting Party considers that it would be useful in the common interest of both Contracting Parties to develop the relations established by the Agreement by extending them to fields not covered thereby
column160: it shall submit a reasoned request to the other Contracting Party. \n The Contracting Parties may instruct the Joint Committee to examine this request and
column161: where appropriate
column162: to make recommendations to them
column163:
particularly with a view to opening negotiations. 
 2. The agreements resulting from the negotiations referred to in paragraph 1 will be subject to ratification or approval by the Contracting Parties in accordance with their own procedures. 
 
 Article 34
 The Annexes and Protocols to the Agreement shall form an integral part thereof. 
 
 Article 35
 Either Contracting Party may denounce the Agreement by notifying the other Contracting Party. The Agreement shall cease to be in force twelve months after the date of such notification. 
 
 Article 36
 The Agreement shall apply
column164: on the one hand
column165: to the territories to which the Treaty establishing the European Economic Community applies upon the terms laid down in that Treaty and
column166: on the other
column167:
to the territory of the Republic of Iceland. 
 
 Article 37
 This Agreement is drawn up in duplicate in the Danish
column168: Dutch
column169: English
column170: French
column171: German
column172: Icelandic
column173: Italian and Norwegian languages
column174: each of these texts being equally authentic. \n This Agreement will be approved by the Contracting Parties in accordance with their own procedures. \n It shall enter into force on 1 January 1973
column175:
provided that the Contracting Parties have notified each other before that date that the procedures necessary to this end have been completed. 
 After this date this Agreement shall enter into force on the first day of the second month following such notification. The final date for such notification shall be 30 November 1973. 
 The provisions applicable on 1 April 1973 shall be applied upon the entry into force of this Agreement if it enters into force after that date. 
 
 
   Udfærdiget i Bruxelles
column176:
den toogtyvende juli nitten hundrede og tooghalvfjerds. 
 Geschehen zu Brüssel am zweiundzwanzigsten Juli neunzehnhundertzweiundsiebzig.

 ANNEX III System of export levy on fish products which Iceland may retain
 Icelandic Law No 4 of 28 February 1966 as amended by Laws Nos 79 of 31 December 1968
column184:
concerning export levy on fish products
 Article 1
 A levy shall be applied to exports of Icelandic fish products specified in this Law. 
 Fish caught by fishing vessels registered in Iceland shall be considered as Icelandic products even if such fish is caught outside Icelandic fishing limits and not processed ashore. 
 
 Article 2
 In accordance with this Law
column185: the export levy on fish products shall be applied as follows:    1. A levy of 2 300 Icelandic Crowns per ton shall be applied to exports of frozen fish fillets
column190: salted fish roes not elsewhere specified
column195: shellfish and preserved fish products in hermetic containers. \n Should the levy applied under this Article exceed 4 75 % of the f.o.b. value of the fish products in question
column196: the Ministry of Fisheries may decide to abolish the part of the levy which is in excess thereof. \n      2. A levy of 3 % of the f.o.b. value shall be applied to exports of whole frozen fish
column202: capelin oil and hydrogenated oils and fats from fish or marine mammals. \n      3. A levy of 5 % of the f.o.b. value shall be applied to exports of whale products other than preserved in hermetic containers. \n      4. A levy of 6 % of the f.o.b. value shall be applied to exports of fish meal
column213:
salted lumpfish roes and other fish products not specified in this Article. 
 500 Icelandic Crowns per 100 kg of contents may be deducted from the f.o.b. value of salted herring and salted lumpfish roes to cover packing costs. 
      5. A levy of 7 % of the f.o.b. value shall be applied to exports of fresh and chilled fish. 
 The Ministry of Fisheries may
column215: decide that they levy on fresh or chilled herring shall be equal to that which would have been applicable had the herring been processed in Iceland by the same method as it to be used abroad (see points 4 and 6 of this Article). \n      6. A levy of 8 % of the f.o.b. value shall be applied to exports of herring meal
column216: herring solubles and herring oil. \n      7. Seal products are not subject to the export levy. \n For the purposes of point 1
column217: uncooked preserved products in hermetic containers shall mean uncooked preserved products ready for consumption in hermetic containers of 10 kg net or less. Fully processed uncooked products in larger containers shall also be regarded as uncooked preserved products in hermetic containers if the exporter supplies proof that the value of the unprocessed product is less than one-third of the export value of the exported products. \n Where Icelandic vessels sell
column219: fresh or processed fish products caught by their own or other vessels and subject to this levy
column220: the said levy shall be applied on the gross value of such sales
column221: less customs duties and other unloading and sales charges
column222:
in accordance with rules issued by the Ministry of Fisheries.  
 
 
 
 Article 3
 The Treasury shall collect the export levy in accordance with the provisions of Article 2
column223: and the receipts shall be distributed as follows: >PIC FILE= \"T0010751\">  \n Payment of the insurance premiums for fishing vessels referred to in item 1 may be subject to the condition that the insurance company concerned be a member of the Underwriters'' Reinsurance Union and be required to apply certain rules concerning calculation of premium rates
column224:
insurance terms and hull values. 
 Whalers may be exempted from these conditions and are then entitled to reimbursement of their contribution to the Fishing Vessels'' Insurance Fund instead of the insurance premiums. 
 
 Article 4
 The levy provided for in Article 2
column227: shall be applied to the selling price of the products
column229: f.o.b. vessel in the first port of landing. The value of products sold c.i.f. or under other terms shall be adjusted to the f.o.b. value in accordance with rules issued by the Ministry of Trade. \n Where unsold products are exported the export levy provided for in Article 2
column232: shall be calculated on the basis of the minimum export price stipulated in the export licence. \n If the exporter supplies proof
column233: within 6 months of the date shown on the bill of lading
column234: that the price of an unsold fish product
column235: as determined by the competent authority
column236: is higher than the actual selling price
column237: the Ministry of Finance shall refund the difference
column238: subject to confirmation by the Ministry of Trade that sale at the lower price has been approved. \n The levy provided for in Article 2
column240: shall be applied to the net weight of the sold product
column241:
which must be indicated in the export documents. 
 
 Article 5
 The export levy falls due as soon as a ship has been cleared for sailing or before landing
column242: should customs clearance not be required. The Ministry of Fisheries may
column244: authorize the shipper to pay the dues when he receives the foreign currency
column245: provided that the transaction is carried out through an Icelandic bank and that he gives the Customs Authorities a promissory note
column246:
representing the exchange value of the sum due. 
 
 Article 6
 Shippers of products covered by the provisions of this Law shall submit to the competent authority before a ship is cleared for sailing or before landing a duplicate or a certified copy of the bill of lading or other shipping documents
column251: together with an export licence. If no export document has been issued
column252: the shipper shall make a declaration regarding the quantity being shipped. \n The provisions of this Article concerning the shipper shall also apply to the master of the ship
column253: in the event of absence of or negligence by the shipper
column254:
and to the ship-brokers. 
 The levy shall be applied on the basis of the information contained in the documents mentioned in this Article. 
 
 Article 7
 The ship and its cargo shall constitute surety for payment of the export levy. 
 
 Article 8
 The competent authorities shall draw up a statement of export levies collected under the provisions of this  Law in accordance with the instructions given by the Ministry of Finance and the rules relating to public accounts. 
 
 Article 9
 Any infringement of this Law is liable to a fine unless another law provides for a stricter penalty. Moreover
column256: ship''s master or ship-broker found guilty of giving incorrect information about a ship''s cargo shall pay triple the export levy in respect of which the fraud was attempted. \n The fines shall be paid to the Treasury. \n Should the competent authorities suspect that the documents referred to in Article 6 are incorrect
column257: they shall inspect the ship''s cargo before shipment or landing
column258:
or shall by some other means obtain the documents necessary for this purpose. 
 
 Article 10
 Infringements of this Law shall be tried under the provisions of the law governing criminal procedure. 
 
 Article 11
 The Government shall be authorized to apply levies on the net weight of the products specified in Article 2
column260:
of this Law in accordance with Article 9 of Law No 77 of 28 April 1962 on the Fisheries Catch Equalization Fund and Article 9 of Act No 42 of 9 June 1960 on Fresh Fish Inspection. 
 
 Article 12
 The Ministry of Fisheries may issue a regulation laying down further directives concerning the application of this law."'

title: Agreement between the European Economic Community and the Portuguese Republic

Avis juridique important

21972A0722(06)




Agreement between the European Economic Community and the Portuguese Republic  






Official Journal L 301
column15:
31/12/1972 P. 0165
 Danish special edition: Series I Chapter 1972(31.12)L301 P. 0167 
 English special edition: Series I Chapter 1972(31.12)L301 P. 0167 
 Greek special edition: Chapter 11 Volume 4 P. 0167 
 












REGULATION (EEC) No 2844/72 OF THE COUNCIL  of 19 December 1972  concluding an Agreement between the European Economic Community and the Portuguese Republic and adopting provisions for its implementation
  THE COUNCIL OF THE EUROPEAN COMMUNITIES
column16: \n Having regard to the Treaty establishing the European Economic Community
column17: and in particular Article 113 thereof; \n Having regard to the proposal from the Commission; \n Whereas the Agreement between the European Economic Community and the Portuguese Republic signed in Brussels on 22 July 1972 should be concluded and the Declarations annexed to the Final Act
column18: likewise signed in Brussels on 22 July 1972
column19: should be adopted; \n Whereas
column20: since the Agreement establishes a Joint Committee
column21:
representatives of the Community on this Committee should be appointed; 
 HAS ADOPTED THIS REGULATION:
 
   Article 1
 The Agreement between the European Economic Community and the Portuguese Republic
column22: the Annexes and Protocols thereto
column23: and the Declarations annexed to the Final Act are hereby concluded
column24:
adopted and confirmed on behalf of the Community. 
 The texts of the Agreement and of the Final Act are annexed to this Regulation. 
 
 Article 2
 The Exchanges of Letters relating to Articles 2 and 3 of Protocol No 8 to the Agreement are hereby concluded
column25:
adopted and confirmed on behalf of the Community. 
 The texts of the Exchanges of Letters are annexed to this Regulation. 
 
 Article 3
 Pursuant to Article 39 of the Agreement
column26:
the President of the Council of the European Communities shall give notification that the procedures necessary for the entry into force of the Agreement have been completed on the part of the Community. 
 
 Article 4
 Within the Joint Committee provided for in Article 32 of the Agreement
column27: the Community shall be represented by the Commission
column28:
assisted by the representatives of the Member States. 
 
 Article 5
 This Regulation shall enter into force on the third day following its publication in the Official Journal of the European Communities.
 
 
   This Regulation is binding in its entirety and directly applicable in all Member States. 
 Done at Brussels
column29:
19 December 1972. 
 For the Council 
 The President 
 T. WESTERTERP  
 
 
    AGREEMENT  between the European Economic Community and the Portuguese Republic 
 
 THE EUROPEAN ECONOMIC COMMUNITY
column30: \n of the one part
column31: and \n THE PORTUGUESE REPUBLIC
column32: \n of the other part
column33: \n DESIRING to consolidate and to extend
column34: upon the enlargement of the European Economic Community
column35: the economic relations existing between the Community and Portugal and to ensure
column36: with due regard for fair conditions of competition
column37: the harmonious development of their commerce for the purpose of contributing to the work of constructing Europe
column38: \n RESOLVED to this end to eliminate progressively the obstacles to substantially all their trade
column39: in accordance with the provisions of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade concerning the establishment of free trade areas
column40: \n DECLARING their readiness to examine
column41: in the light of any relevant factor
column42: and in particular of developments in the Community
column43: the possibility of developing and deepening their relations where it would appear to be useful in the interests of their economies to extend them to fields not covered by this Agreement
column44: \n HAVE DECIDED
column45: in pursuit of these objectives and considering that no provision of this Agreement may be interpreted as exempting the Contracting Parties from the obligations which are incumbent upon them under other international agreements
column46:
TO CONCLUDE THIS AGREEMENT:
 
   Article 1
 The aim of this Agreement is:    (a) to promote through the expansion of reciprocal trade the harmonious development of economic relations between the European Economic Community and the Portuguese Republic and thus to foster in the Community and in Portugal the advance of economic activity
column47: the improvement of living and employment conditions
column48: and increased productivity and financial stability
column49: \n      (b) to provide fair conditions of competition for trade between the Contracting Parties
column50: \n      (c) to contribute in this way
column51: by the removal of barriers to trade
column52:
to the harmonious development and expansion of world trade. 
 
 
 
 Article 2
 The Agreement shall apply to products originating in the Community or in Portugal:    (i) which fall within Chapters 25 to 99 of the Brussels Nomenclature
column53: excluding the products listed in Annex I; \n      (ii) which are specified in Protocols Nos 2 and 8
column54:
with due regard to the arrangements provided for in those Protocols. 
 
 
 
 Article 3
 1. No new customs duty on imports shall be introduced in trade between the Community and Portugal.  
 2. Customs duties on imports shall be progressively abolished in accordance with the following timetable:    (a) on 1 April 1973 each duty shall be reduced to 80 % of the basic duty; 
      (b) four further reductions of 20 % each shall be made on: 
 1 January 1974
column55: \n 1 January 1975
column56: \n 1 January 1976
column57:
1 July 1977. 
 
 
 
 Article 4
 1. The provisions concerning the progressive abolition of customs duties on imports shall also apply to customs duties of a fiscal nature. 
 The Contracting Parties may replace a customs duty of a fiscal nature or the fiscal element of a customs duty by an internal tax. 
 2. Denmark
column58: Ireland
column59: Norway and the United Kingdom may retain until 1 January 1976 a customs duty of a fiscal nature or the fiscal element of a customs duty in the event of implementation of Article 38 of the \"Act concerning the Conditions of Accession and the Adjustments to the Treaties\" drawn up and adopted within the Conference between the European Communities and the Kingdom of Denmark
column60: Ireland
column61: the Kingdom of Norway and the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland. \n 3. Portugal shall abolish the protective element contained in customs duties of a fiscal nature:    (a) either in one stage on 1 July 1975
column62: for the customs duties of a fiscal nature in Annex II
column63: list A
column64: and for the rates which are given there in respect of each heading; \n      (b) or for the products appearing in Annex II
column65: list B
column66: and for the rates which are given there in respect of each heading
column67:
in the proportions and in accordance with the timetables shown in Article 4 of Protocol No 1 for list A of this Protocol. 
 
 
 4. Customs duties of a fiscal nature or the fiscal element referred to in paragraph 1 (2) of Annex II
column68: lists A
column69: B and C
column70:
shall be abolished at the latest by 1 January 1980. 
 The Joint Committee provided for under Article 32 may decide that Portugal shall retain after 1 January 1980 a customs duty of an exclusively fiscal nature or the fiscal element of a customs duty. 
 
 Article 5
 1. The basic duty to which the successive reductions provided for in Article 3 and in Protocol No 1 are to be applied shall
column71: for each product
column72: be the duty actually applied on 1 January 1972. \n As regards Portugal
column73: however
column74: in respect of products listed in Annex III
column75: on which duties have been suspended on 1 January 1972 for short-term economic reasons
column76: the basic rates shall be those of the Portuguese Customs Tariff as shown in that Annex in respect of each heading. Within the limit of the rates indicated
column77: the basic duty to be taken into consideration by Portugal in calculating the reductions provided for in the Agreement shall be that actually applied at any given moment vis-\u00e0-vis third countries. \n 2. If
column78: after 1 January 1972
column79: any tariff reductions resulting from the tariff agreements concluded as a result of the Trade Conference held in Geneva from 1964 to 1967 become applicable
column80: such reduced duties shall replace the basic duties referred to in paragraph 1. \n 3. The reduced duties calculated in accordance with Article 3 and Protocol No 1 shall be applied rounded to the first decimal place. \n Subject to the application by the Community of Article 39 (5) of the \"Act concerning the Conditions of Accession and the Adjustments to the Treaties\" drawn up and adopted within the Conference between the European Communities and the Kingdom of Denmark
column81: Ireland
column82: the Kingdom of Norway and the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
column83: as regards the specific duties or the specific part of the mixed duties in the Irish Customs Tariff
column84: Article 3 and Protocol No 1 shall be applied
column85: with rounding to the fourth decimal place. Likewise
column86: with regard to the United Kingdom and for products subject to a specific duty and referred to in Annex IV
column87: Protocol No 8 shall be applied
column88:
with rounding to the fourth decimal place. 
 
 Article 6
 1. No new charge having an effect equivalent to a customs duty on imports shall be introduced in trade between the Community and Portugal. 
 2. Charges having an effect equivalent to customs duties on imports introduced on or after 1 January 1972 in trade between the Community and Portugal shall be abolished upon the entry into force of the Agreement.  
 Any charge having an effect equivalent to a customs duty on imports
column89: the rate of which on 31 December 1972 is higher than that actually applied on 1 January 1972
column90:
shall be reduced to the latter rate upon the entry into force of the Agreement. 
 3. Charges having an effect equivalent to customs duties on imports shall be progressively abolished in accordance with the following timetable:    (a) by 1 January 1974 at the latest each charge shall be reduced to 60 % of the rate applied on 1 January 1972; 
      (b) three further reductions of 20 % each shall be made on: 
 1 January 1975
column91: \n 1 January 1976
column92:
1 July 1977. 
 
 
 
 Article 7
 No customs duty on exports or charge having equivalent effect shall be introduced in trade between the Community and Portugal. 
 Customs duties on exports and charges having equivalent effect shall be abolished not later than 1 January 1974. 
 
 Article 8
 Protocol No 1 lays down the tariff treatment and arrangements applicable to certain products. 
 
 Article 9
 Protocol No 2 lays down the tariff treatment and arrangements applicable to certain goods obtained by processing agricultural products. 
 
 Article 10
 1. In the event of specific rules being established as a result of the implementation of its agricultural policy or of any alteration of the current rules or in the event of any alteration or extension of the provisions relating to the implementation of the agricultural policy
column93:
the Contracting Party in question may adapt the arrangements resulting from this Agreement in respect of the products which are the subject of those rules or alterations. 
 2. In such cases the Contracting Party in question shall take due account of the interests of the other Contracting Party. To this end the Contracting Parties may consult each other within the Joint Committee provided for in Article 29. 
 
 Article 11
 Protocol No 3 lays down the rules of origin. 
 
 Article 12
 Protocol No 5 lays down the treatment applicable to certain charges for special purposes in force in Portugal. 
 
 Article 13
 A Contracting Party which is considering the reduction of the effective level of its duties or charges having equivalent effect applicable to third countries benefiting from most-favoured-nation treatment
column94: or which is considering the suspension of their application
column95: shall
column96: as far as may be practicable
column97:
notify the Joint Committee not less than thirty days before such reduction or suspension comes into effect. It shall take note of any representations by the other Contracting Party regarding any distortions which might result therefrom. 
 
 Article 14
 1. No new quantitative restriction on imports or measures having equivalent effect shall be introduced in trade between the Community and Portugal. 
 2. Quantitative restrictions on imports shall be abolished on 1 January 1973 and any measures having an effect equivalent to quantitative restrictions on imports shall be abolished not later than 1 January 1975. 
 
 Article 15
 1. Protocol No 6 lays down the special treatment applicable to imports of motor vehicles and to the motor vehicle assembly industry in Portugal. 
 2. Protocol No 7 lays down the treatment applicable to imports into Portugal of certain iron and steel and petroleum products. 
 
 Article 16
 1. The Community reserves the right to modify the arrangements applicable to the petroleum products falling within headings Nos 27.10
column100: ex 27.13 (paraffin wax
column101: micro-crystalline wax
column102: or bituminous shale and other mineral waxes) and 27.14 of the Brussels Nomenclature upon adoption of a  common definition of origin for petroleum products
column103: upon adoption of decisions under the common commercial policy for the products in question or upon establishment of a common energy policy. \n In this event the Community shall take due account of the interests of Portugal ; to this end it shall inform the Joint Committee
column104: which shall meet under the conditions set out in Article 34. \n 2. Portugal reserves the right to take similar action should it be faced with like situations. \n 3. Subject to paragraphs 1 and 2 and Protocol No 7
column105:
the Agreement shall not prejudice the non-tariff rules applied to imports of petroleum products. 
 
 Article 17
 1. The Contracting Parties declare their readiness to foster
column106: so far as their agricultural policies allow
column107: the harmonious development of trade in agricultural products to which the Agreement does not apply. \n 2. The Contracting Parties shall apply their rules in veterinary
column108: health and plant health matters in a non-discriminatory fashion and shall not introduce any new measures that have the effect of unduly obstructing trade. \n 3. The Contracting Parties shall examine
column109: under the conditions set out in Article 34
column110:
any difficulties that might arise in their trade in agricultural products and shall endeavour to seek appropriate solutions. 
 
 Article 18
 Protocol No 8 lays down the treatment applicable to certain agricultural products. 
 
 Article 19
 From 1 July 1977 products originating in Portugal may not enjoy more favourable treatment when imported into the Community than that applied by the Member States of the Community between themselves. 
 
 Article 20
 The Agreement shall not preclude the maintenance or establishment of customs unions
column111: free trade areas or arrangements for frontier trade
column112: except in so far as they alter the trade arrangements provided for in the Agreement
column113:
in particular the provisions concerning the rules of origin. 
 
 Article 21
 The Contracting Parties shall refrain from any measure or practice of an internal fiscal nature establishing
column114: whether directly or indirectly
column115:
discrimination between the products of one Contracting Party and like products originating in the territory of the other Contracting Party. 
 Products exported to the territory of one of the Contracting Parties may not benefit from repayment of internal taxation in excess of the amount of direct or indirect taxation imposed on them. 
 
 Article 22
 Payments relating to trade in goods and the transfer of such payments to the Member State of the Community in which the creditor is resident or to Portugal shall be free from any restrictions. 
 
 Article 23
 The Agreement shall not preclude prohibitions or restrictions on imports
column116: exports or goods in transit justified on grounds of public morality
column117: law and order or public security
column118: the protection of life and health of humans
column119: animals or plants
column120: the protection of national treasures of artistic
column121: historic or archaeological value
column122: the protection of industrial and commercial property
column123: or rules relating to gold or silver. Such prohibitions or restrictions must not
column124: however
column125:
constitute a means of arbitrary discrimination or a disguised restriction on trade between the Contracting Parties. 
 
 Article 24
 Nothing in the Agreement shall prevent a Contracting Party from taking any measures:    (a) which it considers necessary to prevent the disclosure of information contrary to its essential security interests; 
      (b) which relate to trade in arms
column126: munitions or war materials or to research
column127: development or production indispensable for defence purposes
column128:
provided that such measures do not impair the  conditions of competition in respect of products not intended for specifically military purposes; 
      (c) which it considers essential to its own security in time of war or serious international tension. 
 
 
 
 Article 25
 1. The Contracting Parties shall refrain from any measure likely to jeopardize the fulfilment of the objectives of the Agreement. 
 2. They shall take any general or specific measures required to fulfil their obligations under the Agreement. 
 If either Contracting Party considers that the other Contracting Party has failed to fulfil an obligation under the Agreement
column129:
it may take appropriate measures under the conditions and in accordance with the procedures laid down in Article 30. 
 
 Article 26
 1. The following are incompatible with the proper functioning of the Agreement in so far as they may affect trade between the Community and Portugal:    (i) all agreements between undertakings
column130: decisions by associations of undertakings and concerted practices between undertakings which have as their object or effect the prevention
column132:
it may take appropriate measures under the conditions and in accordance with the procedures laid down in Article 30. 
 
 Article 27
 Where an increase in imports of a given product is or is likely to be seriously detrimental to any production activity carried on in the territory of one of the Contracting Parties and where this increase is due to:    (i) the partial or total reduction in the importing Contracting Party
column133: as provided for in the Agreement
column134:
of customs duties and charges having equivalent effect levied on the product in question ; and 
      (ii) the fact that the duties or charges having equivalent effect levied by the exporting Contracting Party on imports of raw materials or intermediate products used in the manufacture of the product in question are significantly lower than the corresponding duties or charges levied by the importing Contracting Party; 
 
 
 the Contracting Party concerned may take appropriate measures under the conditions and in accordance with the procedures laid down in Article 30. 
 
 Article 28
 If one of the Contracting Parties finds that dumping is taking place in trade with the other Contracting Party
column135: it may take appropriate measures against this practice in accordance with the Agreement on Implementation of Article VI of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade
column136:
under the conditions and in accordance with the procedures laid down in Article 30. 
 
 Article 29
 If serious disturbances arise in any sector of the economy or if difficulties arise which could bring about serious deterioration in the economic situation of a region
column137:
the Contracting Party concerned may take appropriate measures under the conditions and in accordance with the procedures laid down in Article 30. 
 
 Article 30
 1. In the event of a Contracting Party subjecting imports of products liable to give rise to the difficulties referred to in Articles 27 and 29 to an administrative procedure
column138: the purpose of which is to provide rapid information on the trend of trade flows
column139: it shall inform the other Contracting Party. \n 2. In the cases specified in Articles 25 to 29
column140: before taking the measures provided for therein or
column141: in cases to which paragraph 3 (d) applies
column142: as soon as possible
column143: the Contracting Party in question shall supply the  Joint Committee with all relevant information required for a thorough examination of the situation with a view to seeking a solution acceptable to the Contracting Parties. \n In the selection of measures
column144: priority must be given to those which least disturb the functioning of the Agreement. \n The safeguard measures shall be notified immediately to the Joint Committee and shall be the subject of periodical consultations within the Committee
column145: particularly with a view to their abolition as soon as circumstances permit. \n 3. For the implementation of paragraph 2
column146: the following provisions shall apply:    (a) As regards Article 26
column147: either Contracting Party may refer the matter to the Joint Committee if it considers that a given practice is incompatible with the proper functioning of the Agreement within the meaning of Article 26 (1). \n The Contracting Parties shall provide the Joint Committee with all relevant information and shall give it the assistance it requires in order to examine the case and
column148: where appropriate
column149: to eliminate the practice objected to. \n If the Contracting Party in question fails to put an end to the practice objected to within the period fixed by the Joint Committee
column150: or in the absence of agreement in the Joint Committee within three months of the matter being referred to it
column151: the Contracting Party concerned may adopt any safeguard measures it considers necessary to deal with the serious difficulties resulting from the practices in question ; in particular it may withdraw tariff concessions. \n      (b) As regards Article 27
column152: the difficulties arising from the situation referred to in that Article shall be referred for examination to the Joint Committee
column153: which may take any decision needed to put an end to such difficulties. \n If the Joint Committee or the exporting Contracting Party has not taken a decision putting an end to the difficulties within thirty days of the matter being referred
column154: the importing Contracting Party is authorized to levy a compensatory charge on the product imported. \n The compensatory charge shall be calculated according to the incidence on the value of the goods in question of the tariff disparities in respect of the raw materials or intermediate products incorporated therein. \n      (c) As regards Article 28
column155: consultation in the Joint Committee shall take place before the Contracting Party concerned takes the appropriate measures. \n      (d) Where exceptional circumstances requiring immediate action make prior examination impossible
column156: the Contracting Party concerned may
column157: in the situations specified in Articles 27
column158: 28 and 29 and also in the case of export aids having a direct and immediate incidence on trade
column159:
apply forthwith the precautionary measures strictly necessary to remedy the situation. 
 
 
 
 Article 31
 Where one or more Member States of the Community or Portugal is in difficulties or is seriously threatened with difficulties as regards its balance of payments
column160:
the Contracting Party concerned may take the necessary safeguard measures. It shall inform the other Contracting Party forthwith. 
 
 Article 32
 1. A Joint Committee is hereby established which shall be responsible for the administration of the Agreement and shall ensure its proper implementation. For this purpose
column161: it shall make recommendations and take decisions in the cases provided for in the Agreement. These decisions shall be put into effect by the Contracting Parties in accordance with their own rules. \n 2. For the purpose of the proper implementation of the Agreement the Contracting Parties shall exchange information and
column162: at the request of either Party
column163:
shall hold consultations within the Joint Committee. 
 3. The Joint Committee shall adopt its own rules of procedure. 
 
 Article 33
 1. The Joint Committee shall consist of representatives of the Community
column164: on the one hand
column165: and of representatives of Portugal
column166:
on the other. 
 2. The Joint Committee shall act by mutual agreement. 
 
 Article 34
 1. Each Contracting Party shall preside in turn over the Joint Committee
column167: in accordance with the arrangements to be laid down in its rules of procedure.  \n 2. The Chairman shall convene meetings of the Joint Committee at least once a year in order to review the general functioning of the Agreement. \n The Joint Committee shall
column168: in addition
column169: meet whenever special circumstances so require
column170: at the request of either Contracting Party
column171:
in accordance with the conditions to be laid down in its rules of procedure. 
 3. The Joint Committee may decide to set up any working party that can assist it in carrying out its duties. 
 
 Article 35
 1. Where a Contracting Party considers that it would be useful in the common interest of both Contracting Parties to develop the relations established by the Agreement by extending them to fields not covered thereby
column172: it shall submit a reasoned request to the other Contracting Party. \n The Contracting Parties may instruct the Joint Committee to examine this request and
column173: where appropriate
column174: to make recommendations to them
column175:
particularly with a view to opening negotiations. 
 2. The agreements resulting from the negotiations referred to in paragraph 1 will be subject to ratification or approval by the Contracting Parties in accordance with their own procedures. 
 
 Article 36
 The Annexes and Protocols to the Agreement shall form an integral part thereof. 
 
 Article 37
 Either Contracting Party may denounce the Agreement by notifying the other Contracting Party. The Agreement shall cease to be in force twelve months after the date of such notification. 
 
 Article 38
 The Agreement shall apply
column176: on the one hand
column177: to the territories to which the Treaty establishing the European Economic Community applies upon the terms laid down in that Treaty and
column178: on the other
column179:
to the European territory of the Portuguese Republic. 
 
 Article 39
 This Agreement is drawn up in duplicate
column180: in the Danish
column181: Dutch
column186: each of these texts being equally authentic. \n This Agreement will be approved by the Contracting Parties in accordance with their own procedures. \n It shall enter into force on 1 January 1973
column187:
provided that the Contracting Parties have notified each other before that date that the procedures necessary to this end have been completed. 
 After this date this Agreement shall enter into force on the first day of the second month following such notification. The final date for such notification shall be 30 November 1973. 
 The provisions applicable on 1 April 1973 shall be applied upon the entry into force of this Agreement if it enters into force after that date.
 
 
   Udfærdiget i Bruxelles
column188:
den toogtyvende juli nitten hundrede og tooghalvfjerds. 
 Geschehen zu Brüssel am zweiundzwanzigsten Juli neunzehnhundertzweiundsiebzig. 
 Done at Brussels on this twenty-second day of July in the year one thousand nine hundred and seventy-two. 
 Fait à Bruxelles
column189: le vingt-deux juillet mil neuf cent soixante-douze. \n Fatto a Bruxelles
column190: il ventidue luglio millenovecentosettantadue. \n Gedaan te Brussel
column191: de twee\u00ebntwintigste juli negentienhonderdtwee\u00ebnzeventig. \nUtferdiget i Brussel

column193:
aos vinte e dois de Julho de mil novecentos e setenta e dois.
